Treatment Methods: Brown or reddish pustules appear on the undersides of leaves. Treatment: Agathi leaves are often eaten as greens or fodder. Avoid systemic fungicides. Prune the infected branches. Spray diluted Sulphur or Neem oil. Ensure the tree gets full sun.

Green caterpillars eat the leaves and tunnel into the flower buds, ruining the edible flowers. Treatment: Since the flowers are eaten directly, avoid harsh chemicals. Handpick the caterpillars. Shake the tree gently to drop them. Spray a diluted Neem oil solution (2ml per liter) if the infestation is severe.
Larvae bore into the stem, causing wilting. Treatment: Inject neem oil into the bore hole and seal with clay.

Caterpillars spin webs around the leaves and flowers (the edible part) and eat them from inside. Treatment: Since flowers are delicate, handpick the caterpillars or shake the tree gently to dislodge them. Spray a dilute neem oil solution. Encourage birds in the garden.

A white powdery coating appears on the leaves and pods, causing them to dry up and drop early. This is common in dry, cool weather. Prune the tree to improve sunlight penetration. Spray wettable sulfur (2g/liter) or a biological control like Ampelomyces quisqualis. If harvesting for food, a baking soda spray (1 tsp + 1 liter water) is a safe, non-toxic alternative.

Brown or black circular spots appear on the edible leaves, rendering them unappealing. Remove heavily infected leaves to stop the spread. Improve air circulation by thinning branches. If severe, spray a copper-based fungicide, but observe a strict waiting period (7-10 days) before harvesting leaves for consumption. Avoid overhead watering in the evening.

Larvae bore into the long pods and eat the developing seeds. Look for small holes and frass. Manually remove infested pods. Install light traps to catch adult moths. Spray Neem oil or Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) during the flowering and pod-formation stage. Regular harvesting of mature pods prevents the population from building up.

Though primarily in the stem, severe infestation cuts off nutrients, causing the edible leaves and flowers to wilt and yellow. Look for sawdust at the base. Inject a Neem oil solution into the bore holes and seal with clay. Maintain tree vigor with organic compost; healthy trees resist borers better.

Leaves show mottled yellow and green patterns and may become deformed. There is no cure. Remove and burn the infected branches or the whole tree if young. Control aphids and whiteflies which spread the virus using sticky traps or insecticidal soap.

The larvae weave the tender leaves and flower buds together with silk and feed from inside. Since Agathi leaves are often eaten raw or lightly cooked, avoid harsh chemicals. Handpick the webbed clusters and destroy them. Spray an aqueous extract of Neem kernel or a simple soap solution. Encourage birds in the garden as they naturally predate on these caterpillars.

Small brown spots or rusty pustules appear on the leaves. Treatment: This vine is very hardy and semi-wild. Usually requires no treatment, but if severe, remove the infected leaves to keep the vine healthy. Ensure it has a strong tree or trellis to climb into the sunlight.

This appears as brown, dry, and powdery internal rot in stored bulbils. Prevention is your best defense: always "cure" your harvest by letting bulbils dry in a shaded, airy spot for several days before long-term storage to toughen the skin. Avoid bruising them during handling. If you find a small infected spot, cut it out and coat the wound with clean wood ash or lime to seal it. Discard completely hollow or light-weight bulbils.

This causes the edible bulbils to become mushy, wet, and foul-smelling. To treat, you must remove and destroy infected bulbils immediately to stop the "ooze" from infecting healthy ones. Keep your storage area cool, dry, and well-ventilated. Avoid washing the bulbils with water before storage; instead, gently brush off the dirt. Sanitize any knife used on infected parts with a bleach solution before touching healthy potatoes.

These microscopic pests cause cracking and dark, flaky rot just beneath the skin of the tuber. Since they persist in the soil and seed, always use certified clean bulbils for planting. If you suspect your soil is infected, practice crop rotation and do not plant yams there for 3 years. For harvest protection, a hot water treatment (soaking tubers in 50°C water for 30 minutes) can kill the nematodes without harming the potato.

Often seen as a bluish-green fuzzy growth on stored potatoes, this fungus attacks through cuts and scrapes. Handle your harvest gently to prevent skin injuries. Reduce humidity in your storage room to starve the fungus. If infection is surface-level, you can wipe it off with a cloth dipped in vinegar. Check your stored supply weekly and isolate any moldy bulbils instantly to prevent the spores from drifting onto the rest of your stock.

The stem swells at certain points. The plant growth is stunted and it may break easily. Larvae are tunneling inside. Treatment: This is a major pest for Amaranth. Pull out and destroy infected plants. Harvest the greens early before the population builds up. Clean cultivation (remove weeds) is essential.

White blisters appear on the underside of leaves. The upper side shows yellow patches. Treatment: Avoid overhead watering. Harvest frequently to remove the inoculum. If severe, spray a mild copper fungicide, but wait 7-10 days before harvesting greens for food.

White, raised blisters appear on the undersides of leaves, while the upper side shows yellow patches. This ruins the leafy green quality. Harvest early if spots appear. Rotate crops; do not plant amaranth in the same spot repeatedly. Spray Mancozeb or Ridomil if not harvesting immediately, but stick to safety periods.

Leaves develop brown, water-soaked spots that rot rapidly, especially during rainy seasons (wet rot). Improve drainage and avoid dense planting. Remove infected plants immediately. Spraying with cow urine (diluted 1:10) or Neem oil can act as a preventive bio-fungicide.

Grubs bore into the succulent edible stems, causing the plant to wither and break. Look for swellings on the stem. Cut open swollen stems to kill larvae. Remove wild amaranth weeds nearby which host the pest. Soil application of Neem cake helps repel the adults from laying eggs.

Caterpillars roll leaves together and feed inside. Hand squeezing the rolled leaves kills the larvae (if you are not squeamish) or pick them off. Spraying a 5% Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) is very effective and safe for leafy greens.

Affects young seedlings/microgreens; the stem rots at the soil line and the plant topples. Use sterilized potting soil. Do not overwater. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride before sowing. Ensure plenty of sunlight and air circulation for seedlings.

Clusters of green/black insects on the stem and leaf undersides suck sap and cause curling. Wash with a strong jet of water. Spray soapy water or Neem oil. Ladybugs are excellent natural controllers for this pest.
Yellow veins and mottled leaves. The leaves become small and brittle. Pull out infected plants immediately. Control the vectors (aphids/whiteflies). Keep the field weed-free.

A specific beetle (Podontia) eats the leaves, sometimes stripping the tree bare (defoliation). Treatment: Look for large, colorful beetles on the leaves in June-July. Handpick them (they are sluggish in the morning). Dig up the soil around the tree base in summer to kill the pupae hiding there.

Maggots bore into the mature green fruit, causing it to rot from the inside and fall prematurely. Treatment: This is the biggest problem for Amatekayi. Hang "Methyl Eugenol" traps on the tree branches when fruits start developing. Collect and bury fallen fruits deep in the ground to break the cycle.

Black, sunken spots appear on the fruit skin, which may lead to rotting. Prune the tree to allow light to the inner branches. Spray Copper Oxychloride before flowering and after fruit set. Post-harvest, wash fruits in warm water (50°C) to reduce surface infection.

A black, sticky coating covers the fruit and leaves, growing on honeydew from scale insects. It makes the fruit look dirty. Control the scale insects with Neem oil. Wash the harvested fruit with a mild soap solution to remove the mold before selling or eating.

Corky, brown, raised lesions appear on the fruit surface. It is difficult to cure. Prune infected twigs during the dry season. Spray Streptocycline (an antibiotic) coupled with copper fungicide during early fruit development.
Rot starts at the stalk end of the harvested fruit and spreads downwards. Avoid pulling fruits; clip them with a stalk attached. Prevent bruising during harvest. Store in a cool, dry place.
Small, waxy bumps on the fruit surface suck sap and ruin the appearance. Scrub them off with a soft brush if the infestation is light. Prune heavily infested branches. Apply horticultural oil spray.
Young fruits drop off due to water stress or nutrient lack. Mulch the tree base to retain moisture. Water regularly during fruit setting. Apply a balanced fertilizer with micronutrients.

Maggots feed inside the ripening fruit, causing it to rot and drop. Set up methyl eugenol pheromone traps to catch male flies. Collect and bury all fallen fruits to break the cycle. Harvest fruits while they are mature but still firm (green) to avoid infestation.

Coastal/Kerala Crop. Large, irregular brown spots with yellow halos appear on the leaves. Leaves dry up, reducing tuber yield. Treatment: Cut off and burn infected leaves. Ensure the soil drains well, as high humidity fuels the fungus. Mulch with dry leaves to prevent soil splash.

This causes the rhizomes to turn soft, watery, and mushy with a distinct foul odor. It thrives in wet, poorly drained soils. To manage it, immediately dig up and destroy any infected plants to prevent the bacteria from spreading to the soil. Ensure you plant in raised beds with excellent drainage. After harvest, wash the rhizomes in clean water and let them dry completely in a cool area before storage. discard any tubers with cuts or bruises immediately.

This infection creates water-soaked lesions on the rhizomes that eventually turn brown and decay, especially in waterlogged conditions. Prevention is key: never overwater your crop and ensure the soil is loose and sandy. If you detect rot during the growing season, reduce watering immediately and improve airflow. When planting next season, treat your seed rhizomes with a biological fungicide like Trichoderma to protect them from soil-borne spores. Rotate crops and avoid planting in the same spot for 3 years.

Unlike soft rot, this fungus causes the internal flesh of the arrowroot to become dry, powdery, and brown while the skin wrinkles. It often enters through harvest wounds. To treat, you must "cure" your harvest by leaving the rhizomes in a warm, shaded, well-ventilated spot for a few days to heal minor skin injuries. Handle the harvest gently to avoid bruises. If you see white or pink mold developing on stored tubers, remove them instantly to save the rest.

Disease Name (Type): Banded Leaf and Sheath Blight (Fungal Infection)
Treatment Methods: While often seen on leaves, this fungus (Rhizoctonia solani) can travel down and rot the rhizome scales, causing brown, scabby lesions. It spreads rapidly in hot, humid weather. To control it, strip away infected lower leaves and keep the base of the plant clear of weeds and debris. Avoid piling soil too high against the stems. If the infection is severe, harvest the mature rhizomes early to prevent the rot from penetrating deeper into the edible flesh.

These microscopic worms burrow into the rhizome, causing dark, necrotic tunnels inside the white flesh, which leads to secondary rotting. Since they live in the soil, your best treatment is hot water disinfection: soak your planting material in 50°C water for 20–30 minutes before planting. Add plenty of organic compost or neem cake to your soil, as this encourages beneficial microbes that naturally suppress nematode populations. Avoid planting arrowroot in soil previously used for bananas or ginger.

This is the most destructive pest. Adult flies puncture young fruits to lay eggs, and maggots eat the inside, causing the fruit to rot. Treatment: Wrap young fruits in newspaper or cloth bags as soon as they set (finger size) to create a physical barrier. Use "Methyl Eugenol" pheromone traps to lure and catch male flies. Collect and bury any fallen, infested fruit deep in the soil to kill the maggots.

Water-soaked, soft lesions appear on the fruit, usually where it touches damp soil. White cottony fungus may grow on the spot. Treatment: Prevention is the only real cure. Never let the gourd sit on bare soil; place a wooden board, stone, or thick straw mulch under every fruit. Improve soil drainage and avoid watering in the late evening. If infection starts, harvest immediately and cut away the rotting part.

Young fruits turn black and shrivel starting from the blossom end (tip), often dropping off. Treatment: This is often due to poor pollination or calcium deficiency. Hand-pollinate female flowers in the morning to ensure fruit set. Keep soil moisture consistent (not soaked) to help the roots absorb calcium. Add lime or crushed eggshells to the soil to boost calcium levels. Remove rotting young fruits immediately.

While this affects the whole plant, it specifically causes the fruit to become small, deformed, and "warty" (bumpy), making it unappealing. Treatment: There is no cure. Remove and burn the infected plant immediately to save the rest. The virus is spread by aphids, so control them using yellow sticky traps or insecticidal soap sprays. Sterilize pruning tools with alcohol after touching an infected plant.
Yellow spots on top of leaves, grey fuzz below. Leaves dry up. Treatment: Trellis the vines to keep them off damp soil. Prune dense foliage. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-agent).

Maggots bore into the developing gourd, causing soft rot and premature yellowing. Wrap individual fruits in newspaper or cloth bags when they are small. Use pheromone traps. Destroy all damaged fruits.
White powder on leaves and stems reduces plant energy, leading to small, poor-quality fruits. Spray wettable sulfur or Karathane. Remove weed hosts. Ensure vines are well-spaced.
Yellow angular spots on leaves that turn brown; it can affect fruit quality. Spray Mancozeb or Metalaxyl. Avoid overhead watering. Prune lower leaves to increase airflow near the soil.
Fruits become bumpy, small, and mottled green/yellow. Leaves curl. Remove infected plants immediately. Control aphids and whiteflies. Use virus-resistant varieties if available.
Orange beetles eat holes in flowers and young fruit skin. Handpick beetles in the early morning when they are sluggish. Dust wood ash on the plants. Spray Neem oil to repel them.
Causes gummy ooze on stems and black rot on the fruit. Rotate crops (don't plant gourds for 2-3 years). Use treated seeds. Spray Chlorothalonil if symptoms appear.

The bottom end of the fruit turns black and leathery. This is not a germ but a calcium lack often caused by irregular watering. Water consistently. Mulch the soil. Add lime or gypsum to the soil before planting.

Almost every wild fig is infested with tiny wasps/flies. The fruit looks ripe but is full of insects inside. Treatment: For culinary use (cooking raw figs), harvest them when they are still firm and green (unripe). Cut them open and soak in salted turmeric water for 30 minutes to drive out any insects. Use pheromone traps in the garden.

The undersides of leaves are covered in rusty brown dust. Leaves fall off early. Treatment: This usually affects the tree after the rains. Rake up and burn the fallen leaves. Prune the tree to improve airflow. It usually recovers on its own without chemical treatment.

This is the most common issue where larvae bore into the fruit, making it inedible and filled with frass. Collect and destroy all fallen, infested fruits immediately to break the breeding cycle. You can protect the fruit clusters by bagging them with fine mesh or cloth bags when they are small to physically prevent moths from laying eggs. Applying neem oil spray early in the fruit-setting stage helps repel the adult moths effectively.

Symptoms include dark, sunken, circular spots on the fig skin which can turn pinkish during wet weather. Prune the tree to open up the canopy, allowing sunlight to dry the fruits quickly after rain. Remove and burn any dried, mummified fruits left on the tree from the previous season. If severe, spray a copper-based fungicide or Bordeaux mixture during the early fruit formation stage. Avoid overhead irrigation to keep the fruit surface dry.

Sudden heavy watering after a dry spell causes the skin to split, allowing yeast and bacteria to enter and cause sour fermentation. Prevention is entirely about water management; keep the soil moisture consistent by mulching the base of the tree with organic matter. Harvest split fruits immediately if they aren't rotten yet. If they smell sour or attract fruit flies, dispose of them far away to prevent the spread of souring bacteria to healthy figs.

While primarily on leaves, severe rust causes rusty-brown pustules on the fruit skin, making them rough and unappealing. Clean up all fallen leaves and debris around the tree base to remove overwintering spores. Avoid wetting the fruit clusters when watering. Thinning the fruit clusters can help improve airflow around individual figs. If necessary, use a sulfur-based organic fungicide, but ensure it is safe for edible fruits and apply it well before harvest time.

This fungus can attack ripening figs, causing them to turn brown, mushy, and covered in gray mold. It usually strikes during cool, damp weather. Promptly harvest ripe fruit; do not let over-ripe figs hang on the tree. Prune dense branches to increase air circulation, which helps the fruit dry out. If you spot a moldy fig, remove it gently without shaking it to avoid releasing spores onto adjacent healthy fruits.

The tree canopy thins out, leaves turn small and pale/yellow, and branches die back (Staghorn look). The feeder roots turn black and brittle. Treatment: This is caused by Phytophthora in wet soil. Avocado hates "wet feet." Ensure excellent drainage; plant on mounds if soil is clay-heavy. Apply a trunk paste of Bordeaux mixture. Mulch with heavy organic matter to encourage healthy soil microbes.

Brown to black spots on the fruit skin; flesh rots underneath as it ripens. Prune dead limbs. Spray copper fungicides during bloom and fruit set. Handle fruit gently to avoid bruising which activates the fungus.
Raised, corky, brown-purplish spots on the fruit skin. It is cosmetic but reduces market value. Spray copper fungicide when flower buds appear and again when fruit is small. Prune to improve airflow.

Rot begins at the stem end as the fruit ripens, turning flesh dark and soft. Harvest fruit with a short stem attached (do not snap off). Keep harvested fruit cool (5-10°C). Avoid harvesting during wet weather.
Small, angular brown spots on fruit with a yellow halo. It can crack the skin, allowing other rots in. Control is similar to Anthracnose: copper sprays and good canopy management to reduce humidity.
Fruit hanging near the ground develops black, firm rot. Mulch under trees to prevent soil splash. Prune low-hanging branches so fruit doesn't touch the ground. Apply a phosphorous acid fungicide.
Larvae tunnel through the flesh, causing decay. Use protein bait sprays to kill adult flies. Harvest fruit promptly when mature. Pick up and destroy fallen fruit.
Causes yellow or red sunken streaks on the fruit; fruit may be distorted. There is no cure. Use only certified disease-free nursery trees. Sterilize pruning tools with bleach between trees.

The plant looks bushy at the top (like a broom) and leaves have yellow/white streaks. It fails to produce cobs. Treatment: Use resistant hybrid seeds. There is no cure for the infected plant; pull it out and burn it. Drain the field well, as waterlogging encourages this fungus.

You will see "shot holes" (pinholes) in the leaves as they unfurl. The central shoot may die. Treatment: Since Baby Corn is harvested very young (within 50-60 days), chemical sprays are risky. Apply a pinch of ash or sand mixed with lime into the central plant funnel to irritate and drive out the larvae.
Larvae feed on the silk and the tip of the young cob. Apply Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Spinosad to the silks. Mineral oil applied to the silk channel can suffocate larvae.
Large, grey, puffball-like galls form on the kernels. Remove galls immediately before they burst and release spores. Avoid mechanical injury to plants. distinct varieties are more resistant.
White or pinkish mold on the kernels; kernels may rot. Plant resistant hybrids. Balance nitrogen fertilizers. Harvest baby corn early before the fungus can establish in the ear.
Large, boat-shaped grey lesions on leaves reduce photosynthesis, leading to small, poorly filled ears. Spray Mancozeb or Zineb. Rotate crops with non-grass species.
Brown pustules on husks and leaves make the ear unappealing. Plant resistant varieties. Spray wettable sulfur if infection is early. destroy crop debris after harvest.

The stalk and ear shank turn soft, slimy, and smell of rotting fish. The ear may drop. Avoid waterlogging. Use chlorinated water for irrigation if possible. Bleaching powder drenching (light) can help soil sanitation.
Swarms of aphids inside the husk make the baby corn sticky and sooty. Spray Neem oil or soap solution. Encourage ladybugs. Check husks carefully before marketing.

The tender emerging shoot turns brown, soft, and rots before it grows tall. This often happens in waterlogged clumps. Treatment: Keep the bamboo clump clean; remove old, dead stems to improve airflow. Ensure water doesn't stagnate around the base. Cover the emerging shoot with a mound of dry soil to protect it from direct moisture and harvest it quickly while tender.

Larvae bore into the soft, young shoot, causing the tip to dry up ("dead heart") and the shoot to die. Treatment: This is common in the forest areas of Malnad. Clear away fallen leaves around the clump to remove hiding spots. If you see a bore hole, the shoot is likely spoiled; remove it. Light traps during the monsoon season help catch the adult moths.

This infection attacks young, tender shoots just as they emerge, causing water-soaked brown lesions that eventually turn the whole shoot into a soft, rotting mass smelling of molasses. To save your crop, ensure excellent soil drainage and remove any rotting debris from the clump base before the rainy season. If infection spots appear, drench the soil with a copper-based fungicide or use Trichoderma bio-agents. Harvest healthy shoots early to minimize exposure to wet soil conditions.

This virus creates hard, brown, necrotic streaks inside the white flesh of the shoot (often called "nails"), ruining its texture and market value. Since there is no chemical cure, your primary tool is sterilization. The virus spreads mainly through infected harvesting knives; always dip your tools in a bleach solution or heat them between cuts. Dig up and burn infected clumps to stop the spread. Always source certified virus-free seedlings for new plantations.

This causes the harvested shoots to become mushy, slimy, and foul-smelling, especially at the cut end. It enters through harvest wounds. Prevent this by harvesting carefully to avoid splitting the base. Keep harvested shoots dry and cool; never wash them in dirty water. If you must store them, trim the cut end cleanly and coat it with a lime paste or food-grade wax to seal out bacteria. Process or cook the shoots immediately after harvest if possible.

Larvae bore deep into the tender shoot, creating tunnels filled with excrement and causing the shoot to rot from the inside. Watch for small entry holes or wilting tips on young shoots. Remove and destroy infested shoots immediately to kill the larvae before they mature. Light traps can catch adult moths at night. For organic control, apply neem oil to the soil and base of the clump during the emergence season to repel the pests from laying eggs.

This fungus attacks the connection point between the rhizome and the shoot, causing the shoot to discolor and die before it fully emerges. It is often linked to waterlogging. Improve aeration by thinning out old, crowded culms from the center of the clump. Apply a soil drench of Bordeaux mixture (copper sulfate and lime) around the clump base. Avoid piling wet soil or compost directly against the emerging shoots during the wettest months.

Very Common. Small yellow spots on leaves turn into brown streaks. Leaves die early, leaving the bunch without food. Treatment: Cut off infected leaves and leave them on the ground (face down). Ensure good drainage. A spray of mineral oil or neem-based fungicides helps protect remaining green leaves.

The plant topples over easily. The underground rhizome is soft and rotting with a foul smell. Treatment: Use healthy suckers. Dip suckers in copper oxychloride solution before planting. Ensure excellent drainage.

The lower leaves turn bright yellow and hang down around the stem like a skirt. The plant eventually dies. Treatment: This fungus lives in the soil for years. There is no cure for the infected plant; dig it out and burn it. Do not replant banana in that spot. Use resistant varieties (like "Nendran" or "Poovan").
The tip of the fruit dries out and looks like the ash of a cigar. Remove the flower remnants (pistils) from the finger tips in the field as soon as fruit forms. Bag the bunches.

The cut surface of the "hand" (where it joins the stalk) turns black and rots, causing fingers to drop. Clean cutting knives. Treat the cut crown with alum or fungicide paste immediately after de-handing.
Grubs bore into the corm and stem, but can also attack fruit stalks, leading to small bunches. Use clean planting material (corms). Trapping with cut stem pieces works well. Apply Neem cake to soil.
Plants are stunted; bunches are small and deformed. Leaves bunch at the top. Dig up and destroy infected mats immediately. Control aphids which spread the virus. Use virus-free tissue culture plants.

Beetles feed on the skin of young fruit, leaving rough, scabby scars that ruin market value. Bag the bunch with plastic or cloth covers immediately after the hands open. Keep the plantation weed-free.
Sandpaper-like raised black spots on the fruit peel and leaves. Bagging bunches helps. Prune infected leaves. Spray Mancozeb or mineral oil during fruit development.
Dark, sunken spots on the ripe fruit peel; the flesh inside may rot. Wash fruit after harvest to remove latex. Dip in hot water (50°C for 5 mins) or fungicide before storage. Avoid bruising.

New leaves are narrow, upright, and bunched together at the top (like a brush). The plant stops growing and won't produce the flower/fruit. Treatment: This is a serious virus spread by aphids. There is no cure. Inject the infected plant with herbicide or dig it out completely and burn it. Do not plant new suckers near infected areas. Control aphids to prevent spread.

Small yellow spots on leaves turn into brown streaks. Leaves die early, leaving the bunch (and flower) without food. Treatment: Cut off the infected leaves and leave them on the ground (face down). Ensure good drainage in the plantation. A spray of mineral oil or neem-based fungicides helps protect the remaining green leaves.

This infection turns the flower tip and bracts soft, mushy, and foul-smelling, often spreading from the fruit tip upwards. It thrives in hot, wet weather. To stop it, cut off the infected flower bell immediately using a sterilized knife to save the rest of the bunch. disposing of the rotting material far from the plant is crucial. Ensure good airflow around the bunch by removing excess leaves. disinfect tools with bleach between cuts to prevent spreading the bacteria.

You will see black, sunken, or necrotic spots on the outer purple bracts of the flower, which can penetrate the inner florets. To manage this, remove and discard the damaged outer layers before bringing them into the kitchen. On the plant, ensure the flower does not rub against leaves or stems, as injuries invite fungus. In severe cases, bag the developing bunch with a perforated plastic sleeve to keep it dry and protected from spores and pests.

Thrips are tiny insects that hide inside the tight bracts, causing rusty, brown, and corky streaks on the flower petals and florets. While often cosmetic on the outer layers, heavy infestation can ruin the texture. Prevention involves bagging the flower early in its development. For harvested flowers, soak the blossom in salt water or turmeric water for 20 minutes before cooking; this drives the insects out and cleans the florets effectively. Neem oil spray on the plant also helps.

This fungus causes the tip of the flower (and emerging fingers) to dry out, turn grey/black, and look like burnt ash or a cigar tip. It enters through the dying florets. To treat, manually remove the pistils and withered floral parts as soon as the hands form. If the flower bell itself is infected, harvest it immediately. Improve field sanitation by removing trash from around the mat, as the fungus survives in decaying plant debris.

Aphids cluster under the bracts, sucking sap and leaving sticky honeydew that attracts black sooty mold, making the flower unappealing. They also transmit the Bunchy Top Virus. Control them by spraying a strong jet of water or insecticidal soap directly into the bract crevices. If harvesting for food, discard the outer layers and wash the inner heart thoroughly in vinegar water. Introducing beneficial insects like lady beetles into your garden can naturally keep the aphid population down.

The pods develop small water-soaked spots that turn brown and sunken, rendering them inedible. Treatment: Use seeds from healthy plants only. Remove infected plants immediately to prevent spreading bacteria. Avoid overhead sprinklers; always water at the base to keep pods dry. A preventative spray of a copper-based fungicide can help protect the remaining healthy pods if the weather is humid.

Caterpillars bore holes into the green pods and eat the developing seeds inside. Treatment: Handpick and destroy any visible caterpillars. Remove any pods with holes instantly. Use pheromone traps to catch adult moths. Spraying a 5% Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) when flowering starts helps deter the moths from laying eggs on the young pods.

Dark, sunken, circular spots with reddish borders appear directly on the pods. Treatment: Never touch or harvest beans when plants are wet, as water spreads the fungus. Rotate crops annually. Remove infected pods immediately. Spraying a mixture of baking soda and water (1 tsp per liter) or a bio-fungicide like Trichoderma can protect new young pods from developing these spots.

While usually on leaves, in severe cases, the white powdery growth covers the pods, causing them to malform and dry out. Treatment: Spray a mixture of milk and water (1:9 ratio) in bright sunlight; it acts as a natural fungicide. Dusting the plants with sulphur powder is very effective. Prune dense foliage to ensure sunlight reaches the pods.

Rust-colored pustules appear on the pods, making them unsightly and weak. Prune plants to ensure sunlight reaches the interior. Clear away fallen debris where spores hide. Avoid wetting the foliage when watering. Dusting plants with sulphur powder or spraying a wettable sulphur solution is a common organic treatment. Early detection and removal of affected parts can save the rest of the crop.

Reddish-brown, powdery pustules form on the pods, making them look dirty and unappealing. Treatment: Avoid wetting the pods when watering. Prune the plant to allow sunlight to hit the pods (sunlight kills the spores). Dusting with sulphur powder is a common organic remedy. Remove severely infected plant parts to save the rest of the crop.

A white, cottony growth appears on the pods, especially near the soil or where pods touch each other. The pod eventually turns into a soft, watery mush. Treatment: Space plants widely to ensure the soil surface dries out. Mulch with straw to keep pods off the damp soil. Remove any rotting pods immediately. Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen, which creates dense, humid canopies that mold loves.

The pods become mottled (light and dark green patches), shiny, and malformed/bumpy. They are tough and fibrous to eat. Treatment: There is no cure for the virus. Remove and destroy the infected plant immediately. The virus is spread by aphids, so control them using yellow sticky traps or insecticidal soap sprays. Plant virus-resistant varieties like "Arka Komal" (for French beans).

This is caused by a Boron deficiency, not a germ. The internal flesh develops hard, black, corky spots, and the center may rot. Dissolve 1 teaspoon of Borax powder in 5 liters of water and water the soil to replenish Boron. Ensure regular watering, as dry soil prevents the roots from absorbing nutrients. Add plenty of compost before the next planting season to balance the soil.

Similar to potatoes, corky spots appear on the root surface. Keep the soil moisture consistent; do not let it dry out during root development. Avoid using fresh manure, which can harbor the bacteria. Lower soil pH slightly if possible, as scab thrives in alkaline soil. Rotate crops and avoid planting beets in the same spot for three years.

Rough, raised, corky patches appear on the beet skin. It doesn't affect the taste much but ruins the texture and storage life. Treatment: Scab bacteria thrive in dry, alkaline soil. Keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the first 6 weeks of growth. Avoid using fresh manure or wood ash (which raises pH) immediately before planting. Rotate crops; do not plant beets where potatoes grew recently.

The main root becomes stunted, deformed, and covered in small bumps (galls) or excessive hairy side roots. Treatment: Plant marigolds densely in the bed one season before planting beets, as their roots release chemicals that repel nematodes. Add neem cake to the soil to encourage beneficial microbes. Practice a 3-year crop rotation. Solarize the soil in summer (cover moist soil with clear plastic) if the infestation is heavy.

The root turns black and mushy, often starting at the "shoulder" (top) or the tip. This usually happens in wet, heavy clay soils. Treatment: Improve soil drainage; do not plant in waterlogged areas. Use raised beds to keep the soil drier. Thin the seedlings early so they aren't crowded. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. A copper-based fungicide drench can help if applied early.

These caterpillars hide in the soil during the day and eat the top of the root or chew through the stem at night. Treatment: Dig around the base of the damaged plant to find and kill the greyish caterpillar. Place a "collar" (a paper cup with the bottom cut out) around young seedlings to protect the stem. Crushed eggshells sprinkled around the plant base can deter them.
Round spots with reddish margins on leaves. Loss of leaves results in small, woody roots. Thin plants to improve airflow. Apply copper fungicide or Neem oil. Rotate crops every 3 years.
Rough, corky, brown spots on the root surface. Do not use fresh manure; use well-rotted compost. Keep soil moisture consistent. Acidic soil reduces scab (avoid over-liming).
Roots turn black and rot from the tip or crown, often in wet soil. Ensure excellent drainage. Do not plant too deep. hill up soil around the base. Remove infected plants to save neighbors.
Not a disease but a deficiency. The internal flesh turns black and necrotic; the growing tip dies. Apply Borax to the soil before planting. Ensure regular watering to help nutrient absorption.
Larvae tunnel inside the edible leaves, creating blisters. Remove infested leaves (Swiss chard/beet greens). Cover rows with floating row covers (mesh) to stop flies laying eggs.
Caterpillars cut the young beetroot seedling at the base or eat into the top of the root. Place a collar (paper cup with bottom out) around seedlings. Handpick at night.
Roots develop galls or knots; the beet is deformed and hairy. Plant marigolds as a rotation crop to suppress nematodes. Solarize soil in summer. Use clean soil for pots.

Small, water-soaked spots appear on the leaves, surrounded by a yellow halo. The spots turn black and the leaf may drop. Treatment: This ruins the market value of the leaf. Pluck and destroy infected leaves immediately. Spray Streptocycline (antibiotic) or copper oxychloride solution, but observe a waiting period before harvesting for consumption.

The plant suddenly wilts. The stem turns black near the soil level. Treatment: This is the most destructive disease. Drench the soil with Bordeaux mixture (1%) or Trichoderma bio-fungicide. Ensure the soil drains perfectly; never let water stand around the vine base.

Circular, black spots with light centers appear on the leaves. The centers may fall out, leaving "shot holes." Spray Bordeaux mixture (0.5%) after plucking harvestable leaves. Improve drainage in the garden. Collect and burn fallen leaves.

Patches of white powder on the leaves make them brittle and unsuitable for chewing. Dust sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur. Since leaves are eaten raw, ensure a strict safety waiting period (15-20 days) or use a baking soda solution (safe) instead of chemicals.

The vine wilts suddenly, and leaves turn yellow and droop. The stem near the soil turns black. This is the most destructive disease. Drench the soil with Bordeaux mixture or Copper Oxychloride. Apply Trichoderma enriched neem cake to the soil yearly.

Small, hard, immobile bumps on the stem and leaves suck sap, causing leaves to yellow. Scrape them off gently. Prune heavily infested vines. Spray Neem oil. Ants farm these scales, so control ant populations with sticky barriers on the stem.

Cottony white masses hide under the leaves, sucking sap and leaving sticky honeydew. Spray a strong jet of water to wash them off. Use insecticidal soap or Neem oil spray. Release ladybugs into the garden.

Leaves develop reddish/yellow speckles and look dusty. Fine webbing may be visible. Mites thrive in heat. Mist the vines frequently to increase humidity. Spray wettable sulfur or a garlic-chili repellent.

Water-soaked spots (often V-shaped) appear on the leaves, surrounded by yellow halos. The leaves turn black and rot. Remove infected leaves immediately. Spray a solution of Streptocycline (an antibiotic) and Copper Oxychloride. Avoid overhead watering. Sanitize your plucking tools.

Black, sooty spots appear on the fruits and leaves. The skin becomes rough and cracks. Treatment: This happens in high humidity. Prune the tree to ensure sunlight hits the inner branches. Remove infected fruits. A copper-based organic fungicide spray can protect the harvest during the monsoon.

You may see sawdust-like powder at the base of the tree or on the trunk. A grub is tunneling inside. Treatment: Locate the hole on the trunk. Insert a stiff wire to kill the larva inside. Seal the hole with a paste of wet clay and neem oil. Keep the tree base clean of debris.
Dark, sunken lesions on the fruit skin. Common in wet weather. Spray copper-based fungicides during the flowering stage. Handle harvested fruit gently to avoid skin injury.

Maggots bore into the sour fruit, causing internal rot and premature drop. Install pheromone traps. Collect and bury fallen fruits deep in the soil. Harvest slightly early while the fruit is still firm.
Black, sticky coating on the fruit surface due to honeydew from aphids/scales. Wash the fruit with mild soapy water and a soft brush. Control the sucking insects on the tree with Neem oil.
Caterpillars web leaves and young fruits together, feeding on the surface. Manually remove webbed clusters. Spray Neem oil or a biological insecticide (Bt).
Waxy bumps on the fruit surface. Scrub off for home use. Prune branches to reduce population. Apply horticultural oil.
Massive shedding of young fruits due to water stress. Mulch the base of the tree. Water regularly during dry spells. Ensure the tree has sufficient Potassium.

Soft, brown, water-soaked spots appear on the fruit, especially during rains. The fruit becomes mushy. Harvest fruits before they are fully ripe and soft. Remove fallen, rotting fruits from the ground. Prune the tree to allow airflow.

While primarily on leaves (yellow spots), severe infection causes the fruits to remain small, shriveled, and sun-scalded due to lack of shade. Treatment: Avoid overhead watering; keep the leaves dry. Trellis the vines to improve airflow. Remove infected yellow leaves immediately. Spraying Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-fungicide) or a mild baking soda solution helps. Ensure wide spacing between plants.
Leaves show yellow and green mottling. Fruits are bumpy and deformed. Treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants. Control aphids. Use resistant varieties.
Circular brown spots with grey centers appear on leaves. Treatment: Remove infected leaves. Improve air circulation. Spray a weak baking soda solution.
The most serious pest. Maggots rot the fruit from inside. Punctures on skin ooze resin. Bag fruits with paper/cloth covers when small. Use "Cue-lure" traps. Destroy infested fruits.
Yellow angular spots on leaves lead to poor photosynthesis and stunted, pale, or bitterless fruits. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid water stagnation. Prune lower leaves.
White powder on stems/leaves; fruits may turn white or ripen prematurely. Spray wettable sulfur. Ensure vines have good sun exposure.
Fruits become bubbly, deformed, and mottled green/yellow. Remove infected plants instantly. Control aphids. Use resistant varieties.
Water-soaked sunken spots on the fruit that turn brown/black. Spray Carbendazim or Copper Oxychloride. Use disease-free seeds.
Adult beetles eat flowers and young fruit skin, causing scarring. Handpick in early morning. Dust ash on the plant. Spray Neem oil.
Galls on roots cause the plant to stunt; fruits remain small and hard. Rotate with marigolds. Add plenty of organic matter/Neem cake to soil.

Bright orange/red beetles chew holes in the leaves, especially young seedlings. Treatment: They are sluggish in the early morning; handpick and destroy them. Dust wood ash or red chilli powder mixed with flour on the leaves to repel them. Deep plow the soil after harvest to kill grubs.

Circular spots with white centers and brown margins appear on older leaves. Treatment: Remove the lower, older leaves that are heavily infected. Improve airflow. Mulch the soil to prevent spores from splashing up.

The tip of the fruit turns black and rots. Treatment: Caused by calcium deficiency or irregular watering. Keep soil moisture constant (don't let it dry out completely). Add lime or crushed eggshells to the soil.
Maggots cause rotting and distortion of the gourd. Bag the fruits early. Use pheromone traps. Collect and bury dropped fruits.
The bottom of the gourd turns black and rots. Caused by irregular watering, not a germ. Mulch soil to keep moisture even. Add lime/calcium to soil.
Dark, sunken spots on the gourd surface. Spray Mancozeb. Remove infected fruits. Ensure vines are lifted off the ground (trellising).
Oozing gum on stems; black rot spots on the fruit. Rotate crops. Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove plant debris after harvest.
White powder reduces plant vigor; gourds may be sunscalded due to leaf loss. Spray sulfur. keep vines thinned out.
Mottled, deformed, or "warty" gourds. Remove infected vines. Control aphids. Keep garden weed-free.
The whole vine collapses; fruits shrivel. Ensure excellent drainage. Use wilt-resistant varieties. Do not plant in the same spot next year.

Similar to Jackfruit, water-soaked lesions appear on the fruit surface, turning it soft and mushy. Treatment: This is common in the heavy rains of Coastal/Malnad Karnataka. Ensure good airflow around the tree by pruning excess branches. Remove infected fruits immediately. Apply a prophylactic spray of Copper Oxychloride before the monsoon begins.

White, waxy, cotton-like masses cluster on the fruit stalk and undersides of leaves, sucking sap and causing sooty mold (black powder). Treatment: Blast the tree with a high-pressure water hose to dislodge them. Release predatory beetles (Cryptolaemus). Spray a soap and oil solution (10ml neem oil + 5ml soap per liter of water) directly on the bugs.
Soft, brown spots appear on the fruit, usually starting near the stalk, leading to total decay. Prune tree for airflow. Remove infected fruits immediately. Spray copper fungicide before rains.
White cottony masses on the fruit skin and stalk. Wash off with high-pressure water. Spray soap solution or Neem oil. Band the trunk to stop ants.
Larvae bore into the ripe flesh. Harvest fruit while firm-mature (before soft ripe). Use traps. Pick up fallen fruit.
Black spots on the fruit skin, often cracking it. Spray copper fungicides. Remove dead branches.
Hard scales on the fruit rind. Scrub off. Prune heavily infested branches. Use horticultural oil.
Foul-smelling mushy rot entering through injuries. Avoid bruising fruit during harvest (use a catching net). Store in cool, dry place.
Black mold on fruit surface due to insect honeydew. Wash fruit with soapy water. Control mealybugs/scales.

Soft, sunken, light-brown spots appear on the fruit, eventually rotting the whole vegetable. This spreads in wet weather. Use disease-free seeds or treat them with hot water before planting. Avoid overhead watering. Harvest fruits as soon as they are ready. If spots appear, remove the fruit and spray a mild bicarbonate (baking soda) solution to alter the surface pH and stop the fungus.

Small holes appear on the fruit filled with waste (frass), and the inside becomes mushy. Inspect plants daily; cut off wilted shoot tips immediately as larvae hide there. Bag fruits with muslin cloth. Use pheromone traps to reduce the moth population. A spray of ginger-garlic-chilli extract is a strong repellent. Remove and destroy all damaged fruits instantly to break the breeding cycle.

While this affects the whole plant (tiny leaves), it causes the flowers to become sterile or green and leafy. Any fruit that does form becomes small, hard, woody, and inedible. Treatment: There is no cure for the plant. Remove and burn the infected plant immediately to stop the spread. The disease is transmitted by leafhoppers, so control these insects using yellow sticky traps and neem oil sprays. Keep the area free of weeds (like Datura) that host the disease.

While primarily on leaves, severe infestation causes the fruit to become scarred, discolored (russeting), and smaller in size. Treatment: Spray the undersides of leaves and fruits with a strong jet of water to dislodge mites. Keep the plant well-watered (mites love dry, dusty conditions). A spray of wettable sulphur or neem oil is very effective against mites.

A unique spotted beetle (looks like a dull ladybug) scrapes the green matter off leaves, leaving a "skeleton" or lace-like pattern. Treatment: Unlike other pests, the adult beetle is slow. Handpick the beetles and their spiky yellow grubs in the morning and drop them in kerosene/soapy water. Spray Neem oil to repel them.

Adult beetles eat notches (C-shapes) out of the leaf edges. Grubs live in the soil and damage roots, causing wilting. Treatment: The notching is distinct. Handpick the grey beetles early in the morning. Apply Neem cake to the soil to kill the grubs. Spray Neem oil on the leaves to repel adults.
Soft, brown, sunken spots on the fruit that eventually rot the whole eggplant. Spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb. Use disease-free seeds.
The plant wilts suddenly while green. Fruits shrivel. Plant in raised beds for drainage. Use resistant varieties (e.g., Arka Nidhi). Do not plant where tomatoes/potatoes grew recently.
Spiny grubs and spotted beetles eat the leaf surface (skeletonizing) and scar the fruit skin. Handpick them. Spray Neem oil.
Mites infest the fruit cap (calyx), causing bronzing and scarring. Spray wettable sulfur or Dicofol. Mist plants with water.
Sunken circular spots on the fruit skin with pinkish ooze. Spray copper fungicide. Remove infected fruits.
The worst pest. Larvae bore into the fruit, filling it with excreta. Cut and destroy wilted shoots. Inspect fruits for holes. Spray Neem oil or Spinosad. Use pheromone traps.

Caterpillars bore round holes into the pods and eat the seeds. Treatment: Inspect the crop during flowering. Handpick caterpillars. Spray Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE 5%) when small pods start forming.
Dense colonies of black aphids on the young pods and tips, causing distortion. Pinch off infested tips (topping). Spray soapy water or Neem oil.
Rusty pustules on leaves and pods. Dust sulfur. Remove infected residues. Space plants well.
Caterpillars eat holes in the pods. Handpick. Spray Bt or Neem oil.
Dark spots with grey centers on pods; seeds may be infected. Use clean seeds. Burn infected debris. Spray fungicide if wet weather persists.
Mottled leaves; pods are small and twisted. Remove infected plants. Control aphids.
Plants yellow and die; roots are black. Avoid waterlogging. Rotate crops.
Chocolate-brown spots on leaves and pods. Severe infection causes pods to drop or rot. Spray Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil. Improve air circulation.

Small, reddish-brown powdery bumps (pustules) appear on the leaves and pods. Leaves eventually turn yellow and drop. Treatment: Avoid overhead watering; keep foliage dry. Prune plants to improve airflow. Dust with sulphur powder in the early morning or spray wettable sulphur solution.

Clusters of small, black insects gather on the tender growing tips and flower stalks, sucking sap and causing wilting. Treatment: Pinch off the heavily infested tips. Spray a strong jet of water to wash them off. Use insecticidal soap spray or neem oil. Encourage ladybugs, which eat aphids.

V-shaped yellow lesions appear on leaf edges, and the internal stem turns black and smelly. Keep leaves dry by watering only at the base. Remove weeds, especially wild mustard. Rotate crops; do not plant cabbage in the same spot for 3 years. There is no cure for infected heads; harvest early if possible or discard the plant entirely to save the soil for future crops.

The cabbage head turns into a soft, watery, foul-smelling mush. This often happens after heavy rains or if the head is damaged by insects. Treatment: Handle the heads gently during harvest to avoid bruises where bacteria enter. Ensure the soil drains well. Harvest during dry weather. Store harvested heads in a cool, dry place. Rotate crops annually to prevent bacteria buildup in the soil.

Small green caterpillars chew many small holes in the cabbage head, making it look tattered and filling it with green waste. Treatment: Handpick caterpillars if you have a small garden. Cover young plants with a fine mesh netting (floating row cover) to stop moths from laying eggs. A spray of Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) is highly effective and safe for humans. Neem oil sprays can also repel the moths.

The edges of the inner leaves turn brown and papery, even though the outside looks fine. This is calcium deficiency. Treatment: It happens when the plant grows too fast or water is irregular. Keep soil moisture consistent so calcium can travel to the inner leaves. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer which forces rapid growth. Mulch the soil to retain moisture.
Small green larvae eat holes in the leaves and burrow into the head. Use pheromone traps. Spray Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) or Spinosad. Release parasitic wasps (Cotesia).
V-shaped yellow/brown lesions on leaf edges; internal stem turns black and smelly. Use hot-water treated seeds. Rotate crops for 3 years. Remove infected plants.
Green caterpillars that move by arching their backs eat large holes in the head. Handpick. Spray Bt or Neem oil.
Roots become swollen and club-like; plant stunts; no head forms. Apply lime to raise soil pH (above 7.0). Solarize soil. Do not replant cabbage in infected soil for 5-7 years.
The head turns into a foul-smelling, slimy mush. Avoid injuring heads during harvest. Ensure drainage. Rotate crops.
Grey/green aphids cluster inside the leaves, making them dirty and sticky. Wash with strong water spray. Use insecticidal soap.
Dark spots on wrapper leaves; internal head leaves may blacken. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid overhead irrigation.

A white or yellow paper-thin patch appears on the fruit side facing the sun, looking like a burn. This happens when the fruit lacks leaf cover. Maintain enough leaves on the plant to shade the peppers. If leaves are lost to disease, use a shade cloth during peak afternoon sun. Harvest peppers as soon as they color up to avoid prolonged exposure to intense heat.

Circular, sunken spots appear on the fruit skin. As the disease spreads, the spots may turn black or develop pinkish fungal spores in wet weather. Treatment: Harvest ripe fruits immediately; do not leave them on the plant. Remove and destroy any infected fruits and fallen debris to stop the spread. Ensure wide spacing between plants for airflow. A spray of Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-fungicide) or neem oil is effective. Avoid overhead watering.

Caterpillars bore circular holes into the fruit, eating the inside and leaving waste (frass). The fruit often rots from the inside out. Treatment: Handpick and destroy any visible caterpillars or damaged fruit daily. Install pheromone traps to catch adult moths (Helicoverpa armigera). Spray a biological solution like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or a neem oil mixture (5ml per liter) in the evening.

The fruit turns soft and mushy with a wet, rotting appearance, often covered in a hairy mold (Choanephora). This usually attacks flowers and young fruits in humid weather. Treatment: This fungus loves high humidity. Improve air circulation by pruning dense leaves. Avoid overhead watering or splashing soil onto the fruit. Remove rotting fruits carefully to avoid releasing spores. Apply a copper-based fungicide if the weather remains wet.

Leaves curl downwards (inverted boat shape) and become narrow. The fruit skin turns rough and corky (scabbing). Treatment: Mites are tiny and love hot, dry weather. Spray a jet of water to dislodge them. Spray "Wettable Sulphur" or Neem oil. Avoid using "Pyrethroid" chemicals, as they often make mite problems worse.
Bottom of the fruit becomes dark, sunken, and leathery. Maintain even watering. Spray Calcium Chloride. Add lime to soil.
Larvae bore into fruit; fruit rots or drops. Pheromone traps. Spray Spinosad or Neem oil. Install bird perches.
Small, raised, scab-like spots on the fruit. Spray Copper fungicide + Streptocycline. Remove infected debris. Use disease-free seeds.
Tiny insects cause upward curling of leaves and scabby/corky streaks on the fruit skin. Use blue sticky traps. Spray Imidacloprid or Neem oil.
Mottled, deformed, bumpy fruits. Remove plants immediately. Control aphids/thrips. Wash hands after using tobacco (TMV).
White, papery patch on the fruit where exposed to intense sun. Not a disease. Maintain leaf canopy to shade fruit. Use shade nets.
Water-soaked circles on ripe fruit that turn shriveled and straw-colored. Spray Mancozeb or Copper Oxychloride. Remove infected fruits.

Small, sunken, elliptical horizontal lesions appear on the root, which darken with age. This is caused by soil fungi like Pythium. Ensure excellent soil drainage and avoid overwatering. Do not plant carrots in wet, heavy clay soils. A 3-year crop rotation is essential. Harvesting carrots as soon as they are mature reduces the time they are exposed to the fungus.

The root splits into two "legs" or grows twisted. This is caused by stones, hard soil clumps, or fresh manure hitting the growing tip. Sift your soil to remove stones before planting. Use only fully composted manure; fresh manure burns the root tip. Ensure the soil is loose and friable to a depth of 12 inches so the root can push down easily without hitting obstacles.

The root splits into two "legs" or grows twisted. This is caused by stones, hard soil clumps, or fresh manure contacting the growing tip. Treatment: Sift your soil to remove stones and break up hard clumps before planting. Use only fully composted manure; fresh manure burns the root tip and causes branching. Ensure the soil is loose and friable to a depth of 12 inches so the root can push down easily without hitting obstacles.

The top of the carrot root turns green where it meets the stem. This green part tastes bitter. Treatment: This is caused by exposure to sunlight. As the carrot grows and pushes up, "hill up" or pile loose soil around the base of the greens to ensure the root crown remains buried in the dark. If you see orange skin poking through the soil, cover it immediately with dirt or mulch.

Creamy-white maggots tunnel through the root, leaving rusty-brown trails and making the carrot rot. Treatment: This pest detects carrots by scent. Use "floating row covers" (fine mesh) immediately after seeding to stop flies from laying eggs. Interplant with strong-smelling onions or garlic to confuse the fly. Delay planting until early summer to miss the first generation of flies. Harvest all carrots before winter; do not leave them in the ground.

The core of the carrot turns into a mushy, foul-smelling slime. This often happens in wet soils or storage. Avoid overwatering. Harvest carefully to avoid scratches. Store carrots in a cool, dry place (0-4°C). Wash with clean water and dry thoroughly before storing.

Maggots tunnel through the lower third of the root, leaving rusty-brown trails. The carrot becomes inedible. Use floating row covers to stop flies from laying eggs. Delay planting to avoid the first wave of flies. Interplant with onions or garlic to mask the carrot scent.

Small, sunken, elliptical horizontal lesions appear on the root surface, which later turn dark. It is caused by soil fungi like Pythium. Improve soil drainage and avoid heavy compaction. Do not over-fertilize. Harvest as soon as the roots are mature; do not leave them in the ground too long.

The carrot becomes forked, stunted, and covered in galls or bumps. It looks hairy and deformed. Solarize the soil during summer. Rotate crops with marigolds or mustard. Add plenty of organic compost to the soil to encourage beneficial microbes that suppress nematodes.

A black, sunken decay forms on the crown (top) of the carrot, often extending down the core. It can develop in storage. Use certified disease-free seeds. Practice a 3-4 year crop rotation. Dip harvested carrots in hot water (50°C) or a biological fungicide before storage.

While primarily on leaves, severe infection causes the carrot root to shrivel and blacken at the crown. Spray Mancozeb or Copper Oxychloride if leaves show dark spots. Remove infected foliage immediately. Maintain healthy soil with potassium to boost resistance.

A fluffy white mold with black specks covers the stored carrots, turning them into a soft, watery mass. Store carrots in well-ventilated crates, not plastic bags. Isolate any infected roots immediately. Ensure the storage area is disinfected before the new harvest comes in.

Leaves become thin and strap-like, and the curd (head) fails to form or is very small. This is caused by Molybdenum deficiency, usually in acidic soil. Liming the soil to reduce acidity usually unlocks the Molybdenum already present. You can also spray a weak solution of sodium molybdate on young plants if the soil test confirms the deficiency.

Rusty brown spots appear on the white curd, and the stem may become hollow. This is caused by Boron deficiency. Treatment: It is not a fungus, so fungicides won't work. Dissolve 1 teaspoon of Borax in 5 liters of water and spray on the soil/leaves when the plant is young. Ensure the soil remains moist, as dry soil prevents Boron absorption. Add compost before planting.

The white curd turns into a soft, watery, foul-smelling mush. This often happens after heavy rain or if the head is bruised. Treatment: Handle curds very gently during harvest; even small scratches let bacteria in. Harvest on dry days. Ensure wide spacing for airflow. Rotate crops annually. There is no cure for a rotting head; remove it immediately to save the soil for the next crop.

Small green caterpillars chew holes in the surface of the white curd, making it dirty with waste and webbing. Treatment: This is the #1 pest. Handpick larvae if visible. Cover young plants with fine mesh netting. Plant mustard as a "trap crop" nearby to lure them away. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or neem oil; Bt is very effective as it targets caterpillars specifically without harming humans.

The plant produces tiny, button-sized heads ("buttons") instead of large white curds. This is not a germ, but stress. Treatment: This happens if seedlings are too old when transplanted or if nitrogen is low. Transplant young seedlings (25 days old). Ensure consistent watering and fertilizing.

The veins of the leaves turn black, and this blackening extends into the curd (head), making it unsellable. Use hot-water treated seeds. Remove and burn infected plants. Do not work in the field when plants are wet. Rotate with non-cruciferous crops for 3 years.

The beautiful white curd turns into a soft, slimy, foul-smelling brown mush. It often enters through sunscald or insect wounds. Handle heads gently during harvest. Store in a cool environment immediately. Avoid overhead irrigation during head formation.

The curd shows water-soaked spots that turn rusty brown. The stem may be hollow. This is a nutrient deficiency, not a germ. Apply Borax to the soil (10-15 kg/ha) before planting or spray a borax solution (0.2%) when the curd starts forming.

Small brown or black spots appear on the white curd, ruining its appearance. It spreads in humid weather. Spray Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil as soon as curds begin to form. Protect the heads from rain if possible. Store harvested heads dry.
While damaging leaves, it can cause internal blackening of the curd/stem. Spray Metalaxyl or Mancozeb. Avoid dense planting to ensure airflow. Remove weeds that host the fungus.

Green caterpillars eat the surface of the curd and leave droppings deep inside the florets. Handpick larvae. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Spinosad. Cover the crop with netting early in the season.

Roots swell into clubs, preventing water uptake. The plant stunts and fails to produce a curd. Raise soil pH above 7.0 by adding lime. Improve drainage. Do not plant cauliflower in infected soil for at least 5 years.
Common in Hills. Mottled leaves, stunted growth. Treatment: Remove infected plants. Control aphids. Use clean planting material.
Maggots bore into fruit. Treatment: Bag fruits. Use pheromone traps.

White, dusty fungal growth covers the leaves and stems, causing them to dry out and reducing fruit yield. Treatment: Prune dense vines to allow sunlight and air to penetrate. Spray a mixture of milk and water (1:9 ratio) or baking soda solution. Apply wettable sulphur if the infection is severe.

The entire vine suddenly wilts and dies, usually starting from one branch. This often happens in waterlogged soil. Treatment: Ensure excellent soil drainage; Chayote hates "wet feet." Remove the dead vine and roots. Do not replant in the same pit. Solarize the soil before planting a new vine nearby.
Maggots bore into the fruit, causing soft rot. Bag the fruits with paper or cloth when they are small. Use pheromone traps to catch adults. Collect and destroy all fallen, rotting fruits.
A dry, brown rot starts at the stem end or fruit tip, often covered in pinkish mold. Avoid injury during harvest. Store fruits in a cool, dry place. Remove infected fruits from the vine immediately.
Brown, sunken spots appear on the fruit skin, which may crack open. Spray copper fungicides or Neem oil during fruit set. Prune the vine to allow sunlight to reach the fruits.
Black, rotting spots appear on the fruit, and the stem may ooze a gummy substance. Rotate crops. Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove plant debris after harvest.
Corky, raised, brown spots form on the fruit surface, making it rough. It thrives in cool, moist weather. Apply sulfur-based fungicides. Improve air circulation by training vines on a trellis.
Fruits become bumpy, small, and mottled green/yellow. Remove infected vines immediately. Control aphids which spread the virus. Sanitize tools.
Insects suck sap from the fruit stems and leave sticky honeydew, leading to black sooty mold on the fruit. Wash fruit with soapy water. Spray Neem oil or insecticidal soap on the vine.

A green or brown caterpillar (Helicoverpa) chews a round hole in the pod and eats the seed, often leaving half its body hanging out. Treatment: This is the #1 enemy of Kadale. Place bird perches (T-shaped sticks) in the field so birds can sit and eat the larvae. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Neem oil in the evenings. Handpick caterpillars if the plot is small.

The plant leaves suddenly turn yellow and droop. The roots turn black internally. Treatment: This fungus lives in the soil. Do not plant Chickpeas in the same field for 3 years. Use wilt-resistant varieties (like "JG-11"). Treat seeds with Trichoderma (bio-agent) before sowing to protect the roots.

This is the most destructive pest for chickpeas. The larvae bore circular holes into the pods and eat the developing seeds. Set up pheromone traps to monitor their arrival and install bird perches to encourage predators. Spray Neem oil or a biological agent like HaNPV when caterpillars are small. In severe cases, apply Indoxacarb. Shake plants gently onto a sheet to collect and destroy larvae manually in smaller gardens.

This fungus creates circular, brown spots with dark rims on the pods, leading to shrunken, discolored, or infected seeds. Always start with certified disease-free seeds and treat them with Carbendazim before planting. If you spot symptoms, spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb immediately. Deep plowing in summer helps bury infected debris so spores don't survive. Practice crop rotation with cereals like wheat to break the disease cycle and keep the next harvest clean.

This appears as a fuzzy gray growth on the pods, especially when the canopy is dense and humid. It causes the seeds to rot or abort completely. To prevent it, space your plants wider to allow sunlight and air to reach the lower pods. Avoid excessive irrigation during flowering. If the weather is damp and cloudy, spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb. Intercropping with linseed can also help reduce the spread by improving aeration.

While this fungus attacks the vascular system, the result is shriveled, undeveloped, and discolored seeds inside the pods. Once a plant wilts, it cannot be cured, so pull it out immediately. Prevention is your only option: plant resistant varieties like "Avrodhi" and treat your seeds with Trichoderma viride before sowing. Delay sowing slightly to cooler months, as the fungus thrives in warmer soil. Rotate crops for 3-4 years to starve the soil fungus.

This causes small, dark brown spots on the pods that turn black, leading to poor seed filling and shriveled grains. It usually strikes during the flowering and podding stage. Use healthy seeds and treat them with Thiram. Spray Mancozeb at the first sign of spots and repeat after 10 days. Maintain proper field sanitation by burning infected plant debris after harvest. Excessive irrigation can worsen the spread, so water carefully and ensure the field drains well.

Small, raised, wart-like spots (scabs) appear on the fruit skin. These spots are rough to the touch and brown/black. Treatment: This bacteria spreads via infected seeds or water splash. Use certified disease-free seeds. Avoid overhead sprinkling; keep the fruits dry. Remove infected plant parts immediately. A copper-based fungicide spray can help protect healthy fruits during rainy seasons. Rotate crops (do not plant chilli/tomato in the same spot for 2 years).

Tiny white moths fly up when you shake the plant. They spread viruses and make leaves sticky with honeydew. Treatment: Place Yellow sticky traps (bright yellow attracts them). Spray Neem oil mixed with soap water. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer.

Major Issue in Andhra/Telangana. Leaves curl upwards (boat shape) and become brittle. The plant looks stunted. Treatment: This is distinct from mite damage (downward curl). Use Blue sticky traps. Spray Spinosad or Neem-based formulations. Mulch with silver plastic sheets to reflect light and repel thrips.

Occurs in the nursery. Young seedlings rot at the soil line and fall over ("damp off") in patches. Treatment: This happens due to overcrowding and excess moisture. Treat seeds with Trichoderma before sowing. Raise the nursery bed to improve drainage. Do not overwater the seedlings.
Circular, sunken spots on ripe red fruits. Treatment: Use disease-free seeds. Remove infected fruits. Spray copper oxychloride.
"Frog eye" spots (brown with grey center) on leaves. Treatment: Remove infected leaves. Spray Mancozeb or copper fungicide.
Round, sunken spots on ripe red fruits that turn black or grey. The fruit dries up and shrivels. Spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb. Harvest fruits as soon as they ripen. Remove and burn infected fruits.
Larvae bore holes into the pods and eat the seeds. The pod rots or drops. Install pheromone traps. Spray Spinosad or Indoxacarb. Handpick damaged fruits.
The bottom tip of the chilli turns dark, sunken, and leathery. Maintain consistent watering to help calcium uptake. Spray Calcium Chloride. Mulch the soil.
Small, raised, scab-like spots appear on the fruit skin. Spray Copper Oxychloride mixed with Streptocycline. Avoid overhead watering. Use disease-free seeds.
Leaves curl upward; plants stunt; fruits are tiny, deformed, and few. Control whiteflies and thrips with sticky traps and Neem oil. Remove infected plants immediately. Use resistant varieties.
White, papery patches appear on the side of the fruit facing the sun. Not a disease. Maintain good leaf canopy to shade the fruit. Do not defoliate heavily.
A grey, fuzzy mold covers the fruit, causing soft rot, usually in cool, wet weather. Improve spacing for airflow. Remove rotting fruit. Spray Chlorothalonil if severe.

Major Pest in Kerala. Plants look stunted and yellow. Tubers have wart-like bumps or galls. Treatment: Rotate crops; do not plant tubers in the same spot every year. Plant marigolds in the bed 2 months before planting (marigold roots repel nematodes). Treat seed tubers with hot water (45°C) for 20 minutes before planting.
Caterpillars fold the leaves and feed inside. Treatment: Handpick and crush the folded leaves. Spray neem oil if infestation is severe.

Brown spots with concentric rings appear on leaves, causing them to dry up and fall, which reduces tuber size. Treatment: Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) if the infection is severe. Remove the lower infected leaves. Avoid overhead watering in the evening.
The tubers become deformed with galls and bumps, reducing market value. Solarize soil before planting. Rotate with marigolds. Use healthy seed tubers.
Tubers turn soft and mushy in the soil or storage. Avoid waterlogging. Harvest when soil is dry. Cure tubers in shade before storage. Discard damaged ones.
Tubers shrivel and develop dry, powdery rot internally. Treat seed tubers with Trichoderma before planting. Store in well-ventilated areas. Avoid bruising during harvest.
White cottony growth on the tuber surface with mustard-like seeds (sclerotia). Deep ploughing. Apply Neem cake to soil. Remove infected soil patches.
Brown spots on leaves reduce photosynthesis, leading to very small tubers. Spray Mancozeb. Remove infected leaves.
White powdery bugs attack the tubers in loose soil or storage. Treat seed tubers with Dimethoate (if not organic) or Neem oil before planting. Keep storage area clean.
Mottled leaves and stunted growth lead to poor tuber yield. Use virus-free planting material. Control aphids. Remove infected plants.
White dusty coating on leaves and pods. Leaves turn yellow and drop. Treatment: Prune to reduce density. Spray wettable sulphur (2g per liter). This usually occurs in dry, cool weather.

Dark brown, irregular spots with concentric rings appear on leaves. Leaves fall off, reducing pod yield. Treatment: This spreads in humid weather. Spray Mancozeb or a Copper fungicide. Keep the field free of weeds. Ensure proper spacing between plants.

This causes large, irregular brown spots on leaves that spread to the pods, causing them to crack and rot. To stop it, start by using certified disease-free seeds or soaking seeds in hot water (50°C for 30 minutes) before planting. If spots appear, spray a copper-based fungicide or Streptocycline immediately. Remove and burn any infected plants to prevent the bacteria from overwintering in the soil. Avoid sprinkler irrigation to keep the foliage dry.

You will see dark brown, concentric rings or spots on the pods, which can cause them to rot during humid weather. To treat, improve air circulation by spacing plants properly. Spray Mancozeb or Zineb at the first sign of infection and repeat every 15 days. Clean up fallen debris after harvest. If the weather is consistently wet, apply a prophylactic spray of neem oil to create a protective barrier on the developing pods.

This appears as a white, powdery dusting on the leaves and pods, often causing the beans to become deformed or stunted. It thrives in warm, dry days with cool nights. Dust the plants with fine sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur (2g per liter) to clear the infection. For a home remedy, spray a solution of baking soda and water (1 tsp per liter) weekly. Ensure the plants get plenty of sunlight to inhibit fungal growth.

This infection creates black, sunken, circular spots on the pods, often with a pinkish center. It ruins the quality of the vegetable. To manage it, spray Carbendazim or a copper fungicide during the flowering stage. Remove any weeds around the field that might host the fungus. After harvest, plow the field deeply to bury fungal spores. Always rotate your crop with non-legumes like cereals to break the disease cycle.

Larvae bore round holes into the pods and feed on the developing seeds, making them unfit for consumption. Handpick and destroy any caterpillars you see on the leaves. Install pheromone traps to catch adult moths. Spray a biological control agent like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Neem oil early in the evening. In severe cases, use Indoxacarb but observe the safety waiting period before harvesting the beans for food.

Leaves show feathery, light green or yellow patterns between the veins. Tubers are small and misshapen. Treatment: Use only healthy tubers from virus-free plants for planting. Sanitize the knife used to cut seed tubers. Control aphids (the carrier) with sticky traps.

This is the most destructive disease, causing small, dark, water-soaked spots that rapidly expand into large purple-brown lesions with yellow halos. The leaf may rot entirely within days. Cut off and burn infected leaves immediately. Spray Mancozeb or Ridomil at 10-day intervals during the rainy season. improving drainage is critical; avoid water stagnation around the base. Plant resistant varieties if available in your region to avoid heavy losses.

This virus causes feather-like yellow or light green mosaic patterns between leaf veins and distorts the leaf shape. The leaves become smaller and deformed. There is no cure; you must dig up and destroy infected plants to stop the spread. Since aphids transmit this virus, control them using insecticidal soap or sticky traps. Always use virus-free suckers or corms for new plantings and clean your machete with bleach between plants.

Look for reddish-brown spots on the older leaves which eventually fall out, leaving "shot holes." It is common in high humidity but less severe than blight. To treat, simply remove the older, infected leaves to improve airflow. If the infection spreads to younger leaves, spray a copper-based fungicide. Avoid overhead watering, as splashing water spreads the spores from leaf to leaf. Keep the area weed-free to reduce humidity.

Colonies of small insects cluster on the undersides of leaves, sucking sap and causing curling or yellowing. They also leave sticky honeydew that attracts black sooty mold. Wash them off with a strong jet of water. Spray a solution of neem oil or insecticidal soap every 5 days until they are gone. Introducing natural predators like ladybugs can help. Treat ants if you see them, as they protect aphids from predators.

These tiny pests cause yellow or white speckling on the leaves, giving them a dusty or bronze appearance. You may see fine webbing on the undersides. They thrive in hot, dry weather. Mist the leaves regularly to increase humidity, which mites dislike. Spray wettable sulfur or a garlic-pepper tea to repel them. heavily infested leaves should be pruned and removed from the garden immediately.

Small, round, dark brown spots appear on leaves, which rapidly expand. The underground tubers may rot. Treatment: Use disease-free seed tubers. Improve drainage to prevent water stagnation. Remove infected leaves immediately. Spray a copper-based fungicide (like Bordeaux mixture) during the rainy season to protect the crop.

This causes a firm, creamy-brown rot in the tuber that later turns soft and smelly. It often starts in the field but worsens in storage. Prevention is key: plant only on raised beds with excellent drainage. Harvest when the soil is dry. Dip seed corms in a Trichoderma solution or copper fungicide before planting. Practice a 3-year crop rotation. If you find rotting corms during harvest, separate them immediately from healthy ones.

The tuber turns into a soft, mushy, water-soaked mass that smells unpleasant. This fungus lives in the soil and attacks through wounds. Avoid injuring the corms during weeding or harvest. Ensure your soil is loose and not compacted. Solarize the soil (cover with plastic in summer) before planting to kill fungal spores. Store harvested tubers in a cool, dry, and airy place to prevent the rot from activating.

This appears as a dry, powdery, brown decay inside the corm, which eventually becomes hollow and light. It enters through cuts. To prevent this, "cure" your harvest by drying corms in the shade for a few days to heal skin injuries. store them in a well-ventilated area. discard any tubers that feel unusually light. Treat seed tubers with a biological fungicide like Pseudomonas fluorescens before planting to protect the roots.

You will see white, cottony fungal threads and small, mustard-seed-like structures near the collar of the plant or on the tuber surface. The tissue becomes soft and rots. Deeply plow the soil to bury the sclerotia (fungal seeds). Apply plenty of Neem cake or organic compost enriched with Trichoderma to the soil. Remove infected soil around the plant base and replace it with fresh, clean soil if the infection is localized.

These microscopic worms cause galls, bumps, or swellings on the tuber surface, making it look deformed and susceptible to rot. To manage, rotate your crop with marigolds or mustard, which naturally suppress nematodes. Solarize the soil before planting.
