Soak seed corms in hot water (50°C for 40 minutes) to kill the nematodes inside without harming the tuber. Add organic matter to the soil to encourage beneficial microbes.

White, flour-like powder covers the leaves and seeds. The crop dries up early and seeds fail to fill. Treatment: This strikes when nights are cool and dew is heavy. Dust with Sulphur powder early in the morning. Avoid dense planting. Spray wettable sulphur (2g/liter) at the flowering stage.

A white, powdery coating appears on the leaves and stems, reducing their aroma and causing them to dry out. It is common in dry, cool weather. Dust the crop with sulfur powder early in the morning. If you prefer a spray, use wettable sulfur (0.2%) or a neem oil solution. Avoid overcrowding the plants; thinning them out helps reduce humidity. Harvest the leaves early if you spot the disease spreading.

Dark, water-soaked streaks appear on the stem and leaves, eventually causing the plant to rot and collapse. It spreads rapidly in wet weather. Use only disease-free certified seeds. If growing for leaves, avoid overhead sprinklers; use drip irrigation instead. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. A copper spray can help protect healthy plants, but harvest intervals must be strictly observed. Rotate with non-umbelliferous crops like wheat or corn.

Tumor-like swellings (galls) appear on the stems and leaf stalks, which distort the plant and ruin the flavor. This soil-borne disease is hard to cure once it starts. Prevention is vital: treat your seeds with Thiram or a biological agent like Trichoderma before sowing. Solarize the soil in summer. If you see galls, pull out the plant and burn it. Do not compost infected plant material.

The plants suddenly droop, turn yellow, and dry up, often just as they are ready for harvest. The roots will show dark internal discoloration. This fungus lives in the soil for years. To manage, never plant coriander in the same spot two years in a row. Use wilt-resistant varieties like "Pant Haritma" if available. Apply Neem cake to the soil before sowing to reduce the fungal population.

Green or black aphids cluster on the tender stems and undersides of leaves, sucking sap and causing the leaves to curl and yellow. Their honeydew makes the leaves sticky. Spray with a strong stream of water to dislodge them. Apply a safe soap solution (1 tsp liquid soap per liter water) or Neem oil. Since coriander is often eaten raw, avoid harsh chemical pesticides. encourage ladybugs in your garden.

The underside of the fruit rots where it sits on damp soil. To prevent this, trellis the vines so the fruit hangs in the air. If growing on the ground, place a tile, wooden board, or thick straw mulch under every fruit to keep it dry. Ensure the soil is well-drained. Remove any rotting fruit immediately to prevent the fungus from spreading to the main vine.

The fruit becomes bumpy ("warty"), mottled with yellow and green patches, and often deformed or curved. The taste may be bitter. Treatment: There is no cure. Remove and burn the infected plant immediately to save the rest. The virus is spread by aphids, so control them using yellow sticky traps or insecticidal soap sprays. Sterilize pruning tools with alcohol after touching an infected plant.

Adult flies puncture the skin to lay eggs. You may see oozing resin from small holes. Inside, maggots eat the flesh, causing rot. Treatment: Bag young fruits with newspaper or cloth covers as soon as pollination is complete. Use pheromone traps (methyl eugenol) to lure male flies away. Collect and bury any fallen, rotting fruit deep in the ground to kill the maggots inside.

Small, sunken, grey spots appear on the fruit. A sticky, amber-colored gummy substance often oozes from these spots. Treatment: This fungus loves cool, moist weather. Choose scab-resistant varieties. Improve air circulation by pruning dense vines. A preventative spray of chlorothalonil or a copper-based fungicide can protect the fruit during cool, rainy spells. Rotate crops; do not plant cucumbers in the same spot for 2 years.

Large, water-soaked lesions appear on the fruit, which quickly turns into a soft, watery mush covered in white, cottony mold. Treatment: This is caused by Pythium in wet soil. Improve soil drainage; raised beds are highly recommended. Avoid overwatering. Remove rotting fruits carefully to avoid spreading the mold. Mulch heavily to keep fruits dry and clean.

The fruit tastes extremely bitter, especially near the stem end. This is caused by heat stress or irregular watering (high cucurbitacin levels). Treatment: This isn't a germ, but stress. mulch the soil to keep roots cool and moist. Water consistently; do not let the plant wilt. Provide some afternoon shade if temperatures are extremely high. Cut off the stem end and rub it against the fruit to draw out some bitterness before eating.
Maggots cause the fruit to rot and curl/bend. Bag fruits early. Use pheromone traps (Cue-lure). Collect and bury fallen fruits.
The underside of the cucumber rotting where it touches wet soil. Trellis the vines to keep fruit off the ground. Mulch with straw/plastic.
White powder on vines reduces yield; fruits may be sunscalded or small. Spray wettable sulfur or baking soda solution. Plant resistant varieties.
Fruits are white/green mottled, bumpy, and misshapen ("warty"). Remove plants. Control aphids. Weed the garden regularly.
Sunken, grey spots on the fruit that ooze a sticky gummy substance. Spray Chlorothalonil. Rotate crops.
Small, round water-soaked spots on fruit that turn chalky white. Spray copper fungicide. Avoid overhead irrigation.
Cottony white mold (Cottony Leak) develops on fruit in wet conditions. Improve drainage. Avoid fruit contact with soil.

Leaves develop bumps or galls and curl up. Tiny insects suck sap from the tender shoots. Treatment: Prune the infested tips heavily and burn them. Spray a soap and water solution. Since leaves are eaten fresh, avoid strong chemicals. Encourage ladybugs.
Small brown/black spots on the leaves. Treatment: Prune the bush to let sunlight in. Avoid watering the leaves directly. Spray sour buttermilk (diluted) as a natural fungicide.

Small brown or black spots appear directly on the aromatic leaves, making them unsuitable for cooking. This is common in humid weather. To treat, immediately prune and destroy the infected branches. Improve airflow by thinning the bush. Spray a home-made solution of sour buttermilk (diluted with water) or a copper-based fungicide. Avoid watering the foliage in the evening to ensure leaves stay dry overnight.

A white, ash-like powder covers the tender edible leaves, causing them to curl, distort, and lose flavor. This spreads fast in cool, dry conditions. Prune the infected tips immediately. Spray a solution of wettable sulfur (2g per liter) or a mix of baking soda and water (1 tsp per liter) to wash it off. Ensure the plant gets full sunlight, as shade encourages this fungus.

These large green caterpillars eat the leaf blades entirely, leaving only the midribs. Since you consume the leaves, avoid harsh chemicals. Inspect the plant daily and hand-pick the caterpillars. You can also spray a strong stream of water to dislodge them. If the infestation is severe, spray Neem oil or a safe biological agent like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) to protect your harvest safely.

These pests create small, bubble-like bumps (galls) on the leaf surface, ruining the texture and appearance. The leaves often curl up. The most effective treatment is pruning; cut off all infested shoot tips and burn them. Do not compost them. Spray new growth with Neem oil or insecticidal soap to prevent re-infestation. Maintain plant health with organic fertilizer to help it recover from the pruning.

This appears as a black, sticky coating on the leaves, growing on honeydew left by aphids or scales. It blocks sunlight and makes leaves dirty and inedible. Control the insects first by spraying Neem oil or soap solution. Once the insects are gone, the mold will stop. You can wash the black coating off the harvested leaves with a mild soapy water solution before using them in cooking.

Dark, sunken, circular spots with reddish/brown borders appear on the large green pods. In wet weather, pink spores form. Treatment: This spreads via rain splash. Avoid harvesting or working in the field when plants are wet. Remove infected pods immediately. Spray a solution of baking soda and water (1 tsp per liter) or a mild copper fungicide to protect the crop during the rainy season.

Caterpillars bore into the large pods and eat the developing seeds. You will see holes and "frass" (waste) on the pod surface. Treatment: Handpick caterpillars if visible. Use pheromone traps to catch the adult moths. Spray a 5% Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) just as the flowering starts to deter the moths from laying eggs.

Dark, sunken spots with pinkish centers appear on the pods and seeds, rendering them inedible. It spreads rapidly in cool, wet weather. Use certified disease-free seeds for planting. If spots appear, spray with Mancozeb or Carbendazim immediately. Remove and burn any infected plant debris to stop spores from spreading to the soil. Rotate your crop every season and avoid working in the field when plants are wet.

Larvae bore circular holes into the pods and eat the developing beans inside. You will often see frass (droppings) near the entry holes. Install pheromone traps to catch adult moths before they lay eggs. Spray Neem oil or Indoxacarb during the flowering stage to protect the young pods. Inspect pods regularly and manually remove any that show signs of holes. Encouraging birds by placing perches helps control larvae naturally.

During heavy rains, pods touching the wet ground or dense foliage can turn soft and rot. To prevent this, stake your plants to keep pods off the soil. Improve air circulation by spacing plants widely. Remove rotting pods immediately to prevent the fungus from spreading to healthy clusters. If the weather remains wet, apply a copper fungicide spray to protect the developing skins.

Reddish-brown pustules form on the pods and leaves, reducing the quality and visual appeal of the harvest. Dust the plants with fine sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur. Avoid overhead irrigation that wets the pods; use drip irrigation instead. Space plants to reduce humidity. Remove crop residues immediately after the final harvest to prevent the fungus from overwintering in your garden.

This causes the pods to become deformed, stunted, and shiny, while seeds inside may not develop fully. There is no cure. Pull out and destroy infected plants immediately to save the rest. Since aphids spread this virus, control them using sticky traps or insecticidal soap sprays. Always use virus-free seeds and keep the area free of weeds that might host the virus.

Maggots bore into tender pods, causing them to dry up and rot. Clean up fallen fruit and debris under the tree to break the pest's life cycle. Rake the soil periodically to expose pupae to the sun and birds. Spraying a dilute ginger-garlic paste extract can repel the flies from laying eggs. Harvest pods slightly early before they fully ripen to save the crop.

The pods develop brown or black water-soaked spots, shrivel up, and eventually rot. This often starts from the stem end where the fungus enters from dead twigs. Treatment: Prune and burn any dead or drying twigs, as the fungus lives there. Ensure the tree gets enough sunlight and air (prune dense branches). A spray of a copper-based fungicide or neem oil during the flowering stage can protect the young pods from infection.

Caterpillars bore into flower buds (causing them to drop) and young pods. You will see small holes and hollowed-out sections in the pods. Treatment: Place light traps around the garden to attract and catch the adult moths at night. Handpick any visible caterpillars. A spray of 5% Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) is very effective if applied early when flowers are just forming. Encourage birds in the garden, as they eat these caterpillars.

Large groups of hairy caterpillars cluster on the bark and pods. While they mostly eat leaves, they can scrape the skin of the pods, making them dry and unfit for market/eating. Treatment: These gather in clusters on the tree trunk during the day. Use a burning torch or a simpler method of scrubbing them off with a stiff brush into a bucket of soapy water to kill them instantly. Do not touch them with bare hands (they irritate skin).

Major Pest in TN/Andhra. The bug punctures the pods, causing oozing gum and dark scabs. The pods shrivel and twist. Treatment: Prune the tree after harvest to remove hiding spots. Spray Neem oil or garlic extract early in the morning or late evening when the bugs are active.
Maggots feed inside the drying pods; pods rot or split early. Rake and destroy soil under trees to kill pupae. Spray Neem oil or Nimbecidine during flowering/pod set.
Larvae bore into flower buds, causing them to drop (no pods form). Spray Spinosad or organic pesticides during budding. Collect and destroy shed buds.
Tips of the pods turn brown and rot, spreading upwards. Prune overcrowded branches. Spray Copper Oxychloride or Mancozeb. Harvest mature pods promptly.
Large groups of hairy caterpillars eat the bark and young pods. Use a burning torch to destroy clusters on the trunk. Spray Chlorpyriphos or Neem oil.
Greyish-white powder on pods and leaves; pods dry out. Spray wettable sulfur. Prune for better light penetration.
Tunnels in the main stem cut off nutrients; pods shrivel. Clean the bore hole and inject petrol or kerosene, then seal with clay. maintain tree vigor.
Yellow aphids cover the tender pods and suck sap. Spray soapy water or Neem oil. Encourage ladybugs.

Irregular brown spots appear on the large umbrella-like leaves. In severe cases, the whole leaf turns yellow and collapses ("die-back"), stopping tuber growth. Treatment: Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or a copper fungicide if spots appear during the monsoon. Remove and burn the infected leaves immediately to save the rest of the plant.
Leaves show mosaic patterns and distortion. Tubers remain small. Treatment: Use virus-free seed tubers. Remove infected plants. Control aphids.

The stem collapses at the soil line. The whole plant falls over. Treatment: Use healthy seed tubers. Treat tubers with cow-dung slurry mixed with Trichoderma before planting. Ensure soil is loose and well-drained.
The stem base rots and collapses; the infection travels down to rot the yam. Ensure drainage. Drench soil with Copper Oxychloride. Treat seed corms with Trichoderma before planting.
Leaves show mosaic patterns; the corm becomes deformed and yields poorly. Use virus-free corms. Eradicate aphids. Remove infected plants.
Stored yams turn dry, powdery, and light. Cure yams in the shade before storage. Store in a cool, ventilated place. Avoid bruising.
White masses on the corm surface in storage or soil. Dip seed corms in Dimethoate or soap solution before storage/planting.
Hard scales on the yam surface suck sap and cause shriveling. Scrub off before use. discard heavily infested corms.
Warty, bumpy surface on the corm. Rotate with trap crops. Apply plenty of organic matter (Neem cake) to the soil.
Leaves yellow; corms develop soft, wet rot. Spray Mancozeb. Prevent water stagnation in the field.

Circular sunken spots with halos appear on the leaves. The leaves turn yellow and fall off, leaving bare stems. Treatment: Since leaves are eaten, avoid harsh chemicals. Harvest greens early before the disease spreads. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-agent). Ensure good spacing between plants.

A white, flour-like dusting covers the leaves (Methi), causing them to yellow and dry out. This reduces the quality of the leafy greens significantly. To treat, dust the crop with sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur. Since this fungus thrives in dry, cool weather, avoid overcrowding plants to ensure sunlight reaches lower leaves. If growing for greens, harvest early before the infection spreads to the whole patch.

Circular, brown spots with grey centers appear on the leaves. These spots can merge, causing the edible leaves to drop or rot. To manage, remove heavily infected leaves by hand. Spray the crop with Neem oil or a mild fungicide like Carbendazim if the infestation is severe. Maintain field hygiene by clearing weeds. Avoid overhead watering to prevent splashing spores from leaf to leaf.

Yellowish patches appear on the upper surface of leaves, with a greyish-violet fungal growth on the undersides, making greens unusable. It flourishes in cool, damp weather. Restrict irrigation immediately if you spot this. Spray copper oxychloride to check the spread. Ensure proper drainage in your field or pots, as waterlogging makes this worse. Remove and destroy infected plant debris after harvest.

Tiny green or black insects cluster on the undersides of leaves, sucking sap and causing curling. They leave sticky honeydew that attracts mold. Wash them off with a strong water spray. Apply a solution of insecticidal soap or Neem oil (5ml/liter) in the evening. If harvesting for immediate consumption, simply washing the leaves thoroughly in salt water will remove the pests effectively without chemicals.

The base of the stem rots, causing the entire edible leafy shoot to collapse and turn mushy. This is common in wet, heavy soils. Prevention is the main cure: treat seeds with Trichoderma viride before sowing. Do not overwater. If rot appears, drench the soil around remaining healthy plants with a copper fungicide. Rotate with cereals for the next season to clear the soil.

Brown, angular spots (shaped like squares/triangles) appear on leaves and pods. Treatment: The spots are limited by leaf veins. Avoid overhead sprinklers. Remove infected residues from the field. Rotate with corn or millets. Spray a copper-based fungicide.

Dark, sunken, circular spots with reddish or pinkish borders appear on the pods, making them inedible. It spreads fast in cool, rainy weather. Use certified disease-free seeds. If infection starts, spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb immediately. Avoid working in the bean patch when the leaves are wet to prevent spreading spores. Remove all plant debris after harvest and burn it. Rotate crops every 2-3 years.

Water-soaked spots appear on the pods, which later turn brick-red or brown. This makes the pods unsellable and prone to rotting. Avoid overhead sprinkling; use furrow or drip irrigation to keep pods dry. Spray copper-based fungicides like Copper Oxychloride to protect healthy plants. Remove infected plants carefully. Use seeds treated with antibiotics (Streptocycline) if growing in an area prone to blight.

A white, fluffy mold develops on the pods, especially those near the soil or in dense clusters. The pods turn into a soft, watery mush. To control, increase spacing between plants to lower humidity. Remove infected pods carefully to strictly avoid dropping fungal sclerotia (seeds) into the soil. Apply a fungicide like Carbendazim during flowering if the weather is continuously wet and humid.

Caterpillars bore round holes into the pods and eat the seeds inside. You will see droppings near the holes. Handpick larvae if the garden is small. Install pheromone traps to catch adult moths. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Neem oil as a safe biological control. If chemical control is needed, use Indoxacarb but wait for the safety period before harvesting.

Reddish-brown powdery pustules form on the pods, making them rough and visually unappealing. Heavily infected pods may dry up. Dust the plants with sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur. Space plants widely to allow air circulation, which keeps the foliage and pods dry. Remove the first few infected leaves/pods you see to slow the spread. Clean up all fallen leaves.

Soft, watery rot appears on the cloves, followed by blue-green powdery mold. This usually happens during storage or transport. Treatment: Cure the bulbs thoroughly (dry them in shade for 2 weeks) before storing. Do not store in plastic bags; use mesh bags or open racks. Avoid bruising the bulbs during harvest.

While starting on leaves, this infection travels down, causing the bulb to remain small, shriveled, and spongy. Spindle-shaped lesions appear on the neck. Spray Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil mixed with a soap sticker. Ensure good drainage. Harvest only when the tops have fully dried down ("cured") to prevent the fungus from entering the bulb during storage.

This is a storage disease where blue-green fuzzy mold develops on the bulb, usually starting at bruises or the cut neck. To prevent this, handle the bulbs gently during harvest to avoid skin damage. "Cure" the garlic by drying it in a shaded, airy spot for 2 weeks before storage. Store in a cool, low-humidity area. Discard moldy bulbs immediately.

These tiny pests feed on the bulb roots and base, causing the bulb to rot or fail to develop cloves. They also open the door for other fungi. Treat seed cloves with a hot water bath (50°C for 10-15 mins) before planting. If the soil is infested, solarize it during summer. Avoid planting garlic in the same spot year after year.

The base of the bulb becomes covered in white, fluffy mold with small black specks (sclerotia). The bulb rots completely in the ground. There is no cure for infected plants; remove and destroy them immediately. Do not compost them. The only prevention is long-term crop rotation (5+ years) and using certified clean seed cloves. Dipping cloves in hot water before planting helps reduce risk.

This affects the neck of the bulb, turning it soft, mushy, and grey, eventually rotting the whole bulb during storage. It enters through the cut stem if the plant wasn't cured properly. To prevent, ensure the neck is completely dry and tight before cutting the tops off. Do not apply nitrogen fertilizer late in the season. Store onions and garlic in single layers with good airflow.

Major Pest: A reddish-brown bug sucks sap from the tender nut and apple. The young nut turns black and dries up. Treatment: This bug is active during the cool hours (morning/evening). Spray Neem oil (3%) or a garlic-pepper spray early in the morning. encourage red ants (weaver ants) in the orchard as they are natural enemies of this bug.

The tree trunk shows oozing gum and "frass" (sawdust). The leaves turn yellow, and the tree may die. Treatment: Inspect the trunk base for holes. Carefully chisel out the bark to find and kill the grub. Swab the trunk with a mix of coal tar and kerosene (or neem oil paste) to prevent egg-laying.

This is the primary enemy of the nut. The bug sucks sap from the young tender nuts (apples), causing them to shrivel, turn black, and fall off (a condition called "blight"). Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin or Neem oil early in the morning. Three rounds of spraying—at flushing, flowering, and fruit setting—are standard to protect the harvest. Remove alternate host plants like Neem or Guava from nearby.

Reddish-brown, sunken spots appear on the developing nut and apple. The affected nuts shrivel, rot, and drop prematurely. It is severe during the monsoon. Prune dead branches to open the canopy. Spray Bordeaux mixture (1%) or Copper Oxychloride just before the flowering season starts. Collect and burn all fallen, infected nuts to reduce the spore load in the orchard.

Disease Name (Type): Cashew Apple and Nut Borer (Insect Infestation)
Treatment Methods: Larvae bore into the apple and the developing nut, causing internal decay and frass accumulation. The damaged nuts often drop early. Collect and destroy all fallen, infested nuts immediately to break the lifecycle. Clean cultivation (removing weeds) helps. If infestation is high, spray a safe insecticide like Quinolphos during the early fruit-setting stage, but be careful of pollinators.

A white powdery growth covers the young nuts and apples, causing the skin to crack and the fruit to dry up or become corky. This happens mostly during dry, cloudy weather. Dust the trees with sulfur powder or spray wettable sulfur (0.2%) during the fruit-setting stage. Since this affects the nut quality directly, timely spraying is crucial.

The internal kernel turns black or brown and rotten, even if the shell looks okay. This is often due to harvesting immature nuts or improper drying. Harvest only fully mature nuts (when the apple falls). Dry the nuts on a clean floor for 2-3 days until the moisture content drops to 8-9%. Do not leave nuts on the wet ground for long periods during harvest.

Yellow, angular spots appear on the upper leaf surface, with purple/grey fuzz on the underside. The vine dies rapidly. Treatment: This is an export crop in Karnataka, so quality is key. Avoid overhead sprinklers. Trellis the vines to increase airflow. Remove infected leaves instantly. Spray mild copper fungicides or phosphonates if the weather is cloudy and wet.

Larvae bore into the tiny fruits, making them unfit for pickling/export. Treatment: Install pheromone traps (specifically for Diaphania moths). Inspect the crop daily. Since gherkins are harvested every day, use safe bio-sprays like Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) that don't leave toxic residues on the fruit.

Larvae bore into the central shoot, causing it to turn yellow and dry up ("Dead Heart"). Treatment: Cut open the yellowed shoot to find and kill the larva. Spray Neem oil (0.5%) at fortnightly intervals during the shoot development stage (July-August).

The plant wilts suddenly while still green. Treatment: Distinct from fungal rot. There is no cure. Remove the plant and soil around it. Do not replant ginger in that spot. Use raised beds to prevent water stagnation.
The collar region becomes watery and soft. shoots can be pulled out easily. Treatment: Treat seed rhizomes with Trichoderma. Drench soil with copper oxychloride if rot starts.

Major Issue in Andhra. The base of the stem turns black and rots near the soil line. The plant suddenly wilts and topples over. Treatment: This occurs in waterlogged heavy soils (black cotton soil). Improve field drainage; do not let water stand. Drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride or Trichoderma. Rotate crops; do not plant Gongura in the same spot every year.

The base of the stem turns black and rots. The plant topples over. Treatment: This occurs in waterlogged heavy soils (black cotton soil). Improve drainage. Drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride or Trichoderma. Rotate crops; do not plant Gongura in the same spot every year.

Bright yellow patches appear on the leaves interspersed with green. Pods remain small and yellow. Treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. The virus is spread by Whiteflies. Control them using yellow sticky traps and neem oil sprays. Keep the field weed-free.

Greyish-white powder covers the leaves and pods. The plant dries up early. Treatment: Spray sulphur powder or a solution of wet milk (1:10 ratio) on the crop. This usually strikes when the weather turns dry and cool after rains.

The beetle hollows out the green berries (peppercorns), leaving them empty and black. Treatment: Regulate shade in the plantation (too much shade favors the beetle). Spray Neem-based insecticides on the spikes (berries) when they are young and tender.

A white, cottony fungal growth appears on the stem near the soil line. The plant wilts and dies. Treatment: This fungus survives in the soil. Deep plow in summer to expose it to the sun. Apply Trichoderma (bio-fungicide) enriched manure to the soil.

Black spots appear on the leaves and stems. The vine looks "scorched" or burnt and dies back rapidly. Treatment: This is the most destructive disease for this yam. Plant early so the vine matures before the peak monsoon. Use resistant local varieties. Dip seed tubers in a solution of cow dung slurry and Trichoderma before planting.

Brown, corky, raised rough spots appear on the fruit skin and leaves. Treatment: Prune infected twigs before the monsoon. Spray a copper-based fungicide (like Bordeaux mixture) on the new leaves and young fruits. Avoid overhead watering. The fruit inside is usually safe to use for pickling even if the skin is rough.

Silvery, snake-like trails appear on the young tender leaves, causing them to curl. Treatment: This only attacks new growth. Pinch off and destroy the curled leaves. Spray Neem oil (10,000 ppm) on the fresh flush of leaves to deter the moth from laying eggs.

Bright yellow patches appear on the leaves, while the veins remain green. The plants produce very few pods. Treatment: This is the most common issue for Huruli. There is no cure for the plant. Remove infected plants immediately. The virus is spread by Whiteflies. Control them by placing yellow sticky traps (10 per acre) and spraying neem oil early in the season.

The plant suddenly wilts and dries up in patches across the field. If you pull it up, the roots are black and decaying. Treatment: This usually happens if there is standing water. Improve field drainage. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (bio-fungicide) before sowing. Practice crop rotation; do not plant horse gram in the same field continuously.
Swellings or galls appear on the main stem. Treatment: Earth up soil around nodes to encourage new roots. Apply neem cake. Remove affected plant if it wilts completely.

Soft, watery brown spots appear on the young jackfruit, which soon get covered in a grey-black hairy mold. The fruit rots and falls. Treatment: This spreads rapidly in humid weather. Remove and bury any rotting fruit immediately. Avoid injuring the fruit skin during maintenance. Spray a copper-based fungicide (like Bordeaux mixture) on young fruits before the rains start.

Caterpillars bore into the tender shoots and flower buds, causing them to dry up. They also tunnel into the fruit, making it rot. Treatment: Prune and burn the wilted shoots where larvae hide. Cover developing fruits with bags if possible. Light traps can catch adult moths. Spray neem oil on tender shoots during the new flush season.

Tiny insects suck sap from the flower spikes. Sticky "honeydew" falls on leaves, turning them black (sooty mold). Fruits fail to set. Treatment: This is critical for Appemidi. Spray a strong jet of water on the flowers to wash off the sticky gum. Smoke the tree by burning neem leaves underneath in the early morning to drive away the hoppers.

Black, sunken spots appear on the fruit skin, often leading to deep rot as the fruit ripens. It also causes "tear staining." Prune the tree to open the canopy to sunlight. Spray Copper Oxychloride before flowering and again during fruit set. Dip harvested fruits in hot water (52°C) for 5 minutes to kill surface fungus before storage.

The grub bores through the pulp and eats the seed (stone) from the inside. The fruit looks normal outside but rots from within. Collect all fallen fruits and destroy them. Spray Deltamethrin on the trunk during the off-season to kill hiding adults. There is no cure for an infested fruit; prevention is the only key.

A black, velvety coating covers the fruit surface, making it look dirty and unmarketable. It grows on the sticky honeydew left by hoppers and scale insects. Control the insects first with Neem oil. Wash the harvested fruit with a mild soap solution and a soft cloth to remove the black layer; the fruit inside remains edible.

Water-soaked spots on the fruit burst and release a gummy ooze. The fruit cracks and drops. This is severe in windy, wet areas. Prune infected twigs. Spray Streptocycline (antibiotic) mixed with Copper fungicide. Use windbreaks to prevent fruit abrasion, which allows bacteria to enter.

While mostly on flowers, it can cause young fruits to drop or develop russeted, scabby skin. Dust sulfur powder on the tree during flowering. Ensure good air circulation. If the fruit skin is affected, it is still edible but looks rough; peel it before eating.

Rusty red spots appear on the leaves and sometimes on the fruit surface, reducing vigor. It is caused by an alga, not a fungus. Prune the tree to reduce humidity. Spray Bordeaux mixture or copper fungicides. Ensure the tree gets adequate nutrition to fight off the infection.

Maggots bore into the semi-ripe fruit, turning the flesh into a liquid, rotting mush. This is the biggest threat. Set up pheromone traps (Methyl Eugenol) 2 months before harvest. Collect and bury all fallen fruits deep in the soil. Harvest fruits while they are mature but green (before they soften) to avoid the peak infestation window.

Plants wilt during the day and recover at night. Roots become swollen, club-like, and deformed, unable to absorb water. Treatment: This fungus thrives in acidic soil. Add lime to the soil to raise the pH. Improve drainage. Do not plant Knol Khol, Cabbage, or Cauliflower in the infected spot for at least 5 years.

The fleshy tuber turns into a soft, watery, smelly mush. It often enters through growth cracks or insect wounds. Harvest carefully to avoid bruises. Store in a cool, dry place. Ensure soil drains well, as waterlogging promotes this rot.

The roots swell and deform, preventing the tuber from developing properly. The plant stunts. Apply lime to raise soil pH above 7.0. Solarize the soil. Do not plant Knol Khol in infected fields for at least 5 years.
Purplish-grey mold on leaves leads to poor tuber development and internal discoloration. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid overcrowding plants. Remove weeds that block airflow.
Brown concentric spots on leaves reduce photosynthesis, leading to small, woody tubers. Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove infected leaves.
Maggots tunnel into the root and base of the tuber, causing rot and wilting. Use floating row covers. Apply Neem cake to the soil.
Large colonies suck sap, causing the tuber to be small and the leaves to curl. Wash off with water spray. Use insecticidal soap.

The veins of the leaves turn black, and the infection travels down into the edible stem tuber, causing internal blackening. Use hot-water treated seeds. Rotate crops; do not plant where cabbage grew recently. Remove infected plants immediately. Avoid sprinkler irrigation to keep the plant dry.

Leaves show a patchwork of dark and light green. The leaves pucker and curl downwards. Pods are deformed. Treatment: Use virus-free seeds. Remove infected plants immediately. Control Aphids (which spread the virus) using sticky traps and Neem oil sprays.

Entire crop can be defoliated (stripped of leaves) by these hairy orange/black caterpillars in days. Treatment: They feed in groups when young. Pick the single leaf with the cluster of young caterpillars and destroy it. Dig a trench around the field to stop them from migrating. Spray Neem oil or Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis).
Round, sunken spots with red borders on pods. Seeds rot inside. Spray Mancozeb. Use disease-free seeds. Remove infected debris.
Black aphids cover the vines and pods, making them sticky and sooty. Spray soapy water. Encourage ladybugs.
Brown pustules on leaves and pods. Dust sulfur. Remove crop residues. Space plants for airflow.
Bright yellow patches on leaves; pods are deformed and few. Control whiteflies. Remove infected plants.
Vines wilt and die. Roots are black. Improve drainage. Treat seeds with Trichoderma.
White powder on pods and leaves. Spray wettable sulfur. Avoid shade.
Larvae bore into the flat pods and eat the fresh seeds. Handpick damaged pods. Spray Neem oil or Indoxacarb. Install pheromone traps.

While systemic, this virus turns pods small, pale, fibrous, and tough. The virus is spread by whiteflies. There is no cure for the plant; remove and burn it to stop the spread. Control whiteflies using yellow sticky traps and neem oil sprays. Plant resistant varieties like "Arka Anamika." Keep the garden weed-free as weeds often host the virus.
Veins turn yellow; fruits become pale, hard, fibrous, and small. Remove infected plants instantly. Control whiteflies with sticky traps/Neem oil. Use resistant varieties (e.g., Arka Anamika).
White powder on leaves and pods; pods look dirty and dry. Spray wettable sulfur. Prune lower leaves.
Brown spots on leaves cause defoliation and poor fruit yield. Spray Mancozeb. Remove weeds.
Plants yellow and die; vascular system turns brown. Rotate crops. Soil drench with Carbendazim.
Galls on roots; plants stunt; low yield. Solarize soil. Rotate with marigolds. Apply Neem cake.
Pods rot during wet weather. Pick fruits regularly (don't let them over-mature). Spray copper fungicide if raining.
Larvae bore into the fruit, leaving holes and frass. The pod becomes distorted and inedible. Remove and destroy infested shoots/fruits. Spray Neem oil or Spinosad. Use pheromone traps.

Adult beetles bore into the tubers in the ground, making large circular holes that rot. Treatment: Dust wood ash or apply Neem cake to the planting pit. Do not plant yams in the same spot for 3 years. Mulch the soil heavily to make it harder for beetles to dig down.
Leaves burn and die back; tubers stop growing. Spray Mancozeb. Plant early to avoid peak monsoon infection.
Leaves show mosaic patterns; tubers are small. Use virus-free seed tubers. Control aphids.
Tubers rot in storage. Cure tubers in shade. Store in well-ventilated racks. Avoid bruising.
Cracks and galls on tuber skin. Use clean seed. Hot water treatment (50°C) for seed tubers.
Scales on stored tubers suck sap, causing shriveling. Dip tubers in soap solution before storage.
White powdery bugs on tubers. Clean tubers before storage.
Brown spots reduce leaf area. Spray Carbendazim.

Common in Ooty/Kodaikanal/Chikmagalur. Pods turn brown and dry up prematurely. Seeds inside become shriveled. Treatment: This happens in cool, misty weather. Improve airflow by spacing plants widely. Spray a mild fungicide like Mancozeb (2g/liter) during the flowering stage. Remove infected pods immediately.

Clusters of black insects attack the young shoots and pods, sucking sap and causing the plant to curl. Treatment: Spray a strong jet of water to wash them off. Use insecticidal soap or neem oil. Encourage ladybug beetles in the garden.
Pods turn brown and rot. Spray Copper Oxychloride. Improve spacing.
Sunken spots on pods. Use clean seed. Spray Mancozeb.
Red pustules on leaves/pods. Dust sulfur.
Mottled, deformed pods. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Holes in pods. Spray Neem oil. Handpick.
Plants wilt. Improve drainage. Treat seeds.
White dust on pods. Spray sulfur.

Small, dark, sunken spots appear on the fruits and stems. In wet weather, pinkish spores may form. Treatment: Prune the vines heavily to reduce humidity inside the trellis. Remove and destroy infected fruits. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-fungicide) or neem oil.
Leaves turn reddish-brown and look "scorched." Tiny webs may be seen. Treatment: Mites thrive in hot, dry weather. Spray water forcefully to wash them off. Apply wettable sulphur (2g/liter).
White powder on vines/fruit. Spray wettable sulfur. Prune dense vines.
Dark spots on fruit. Spray Mancozeb.
Lumpy, mottled fruits. Remove vines. Control aphids.
Larvae eat fruit. Spray Neem oil.
Yellow spots on leaves; poor fruit set. Spray Metalaxyl.
Galls on roots; low yield. Apply Neem cake.
Maggots rot the fruit. Use Cue-lure traps. Bag fruits. Harvest frequently.

This large, yellow cucumber is a magnet for fruit flies. Maggots turn the inside into mush. Treatment: Unlike salad cucumbers, these have thick skin, but flies still pierce them. Cover the fruit with a cloth bag or newspaper as soon as the flower drops. Use pheromone traps. Harvest as soon as the colour begins to change to yellow; do not leave it on the vine too long.

White dusty patches cover the large leaves, killing the vine before fruits mature. Treatment: This variety is often grown on the ground, making it susceptible. Try to grow on a trellis or use mulch (dry straw) to prevent leaves from touching soil. Spray wettable sulphur or a milk-water mix.
Maggots cause rotting and bending. Trap males. Bag fruits. Destroy fallen ones.
Yellow leaf spots; fruit sunscalds or stays small. Spray Mancozeb.
White powder; fruits dry up. Spray sulfur.
"Warty" deformed fruits. Remove plants. Control vectors.
Sunken pinkish spots on fruit. Spray Copper fungicide.
Black rot on fruit; gum on stem. Rotate crops. Spray Chlorothalonil.
Underside rots on soil. Mulch or trellis.

Round, reddish-purple spots with a pale center appear on the thick leaves. Makes the leaves look unappetizing. Treatment: Basale is very hardy, but this happens in high humidity. Remove the infected leaves (don't eat them). Improve airflow by training vines properly. Avoid wetting the leaves when watering.

Round, reddish-purple spots with a pale center appear on the thick leaves. Treatment: Remove the infected leaves (do not eat them). Improve airflow by training vines properly. Avoid wetting the leaves when watering in the evening.
Red/purple spots with pale centers on the edible leaves. Pick off infected leaves. Spray Neem oil. Avoid overhead watering.
Orange/yellow pustules on leaves. Remove bad leaves. Dust sulfur (wash well before eating).
Roots have galls; plant stunts. Solarize soil. Rotate crops.
Stem rots at soil line. Improve drainage. Do not overwater.
Trails in leaves. Remove leaves. Spray Neem oil.
White fuzzy insects on stems. Wash off. Spray soap solution.
Brown irregular spots. Remove leaves. Ensure airflow.

Maggots bore into the large yellow fruit, causing soft rot. Treatment: Since this cucumber is often left on the vine to mature fully (turn yellow/orange), it is exposed for a long time. Cover the fruit with a cloth bag or newspaper once it reaches the size of a fist. Use pheromone traps.

The leaves turn yellow and dry up from the tip. The underground rhizome turns soft and mushy with a foul smell. Treatment: This is the biggest threat to this crop. Prevention is key. Treat seed rhizomes with Trichoderma or hot water (50°C for 30 mins) before planting. Ensure the bed is raised and has excellent drainage. If rot starts, drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride.

Numerous small, round, brown spots appear on the leaves, causing them to dry up early. This reduces the rhizome size. Treatment: This usually happens in the rainy season. Remove heavily infected leaves. Spray a mild solution of Mancozeb (2g/liter) or an organic copper spray to check the spread.
Soft rot of the rhizome. Ensure drainage. Treat seed with Mancozeb.
Brown spots reduce yield. Spray Carbendazim.
Dead heart in stem. Cut and burn. Spray Neem oil.
Scales on rhizome in storage. Clean before storing.
Lesions on rhizome. Use clean seed. Apply Neem cake.
Dry decay in storage. Cure properly. Store in sand.
Rapid wilting. Use certified seed. Solarize soil.

Green patches (Trichoderma) appear on the casing soil or mushroom bags, competing with the mushroom spawn. Treatment: This is caused by poor hygiene. Sterilize the straw/substrate thoroughly. If a green spot appears, cover it immediately with salt or a damp cloth soaked in vinegar to stop spores from flying, then remove the bag carefully.
Brown, slimy spots on the mushroom cap. Reduce humidity. Chlorinate water (150ppm). Avoid water staying on caps.
Green patches on the casing soil or mushroom. Use pasteurized soil. Remove infected bags immediately. Maintain hygiene.
Deformed mushrooms with bulbous bases. Control fungus gnats. Use clean casing.
Mushrooms become a shapeless, rotting mass with amber liquid drops. Cover infected area with salt/lime. Steam sterilize casing soil.
Black, inky mushrooms appear in the bed. Indicates poor compost ammonia levels. Remove them before they liquify.
Larvae eat mushroom mycelium and tunnel into caps. Use light traps. seal the growing room.
Mushrooms are small, leathery, or deformed. Disinfect the room. Use virus-free spawn.

Small, dusty, bright orange or brown spots appear on the undersides of leaves. The leaves yellow and drop, ruining the harvest. Treatment: Avoid overhead watering; keep leaves dry. Harvest stems frequently to remove the fungus before it spreads. If severe, cut the entire patch down to the ground and let fresh, clean shoots grow back.

The underground runners (stolons) turn brown and rot. The patch becomes thin and dies out in spots. Treatment: This happens in waterlogged soil. Replant the patch in a new, well-drained raised bed. Dip new planting roots in a mild fungicide or Trichoderma slurry before planting.
White powder on leaves. Spray baking soda solution or wettable sulfur. Harvest frequently to keep air flowing.
Plants twist, stunt, and die. Soil-borne fungus. Do not replant mint in the same spot. Solarize soil.
Large irregular brown spots. Remove leaves. Avoid wet foliage.
Green insects on tips. Wash off with water. Spray soap solution.
Stems cut at base. Handpick larvae in soil.
Caterpillars eat leaves. Handpick. Spray Bt.

Orange/brown pustules on the undersides of leaves. This is serious. Use disease-free cuttings. Propane flaming is used in commercial fields, but for home, remove infected stems. Do not overhead water.

Green patches of Trichoderma mold appear on the mushroom growing bags or casing soil, competing with the mushrooms. Treatment: This is caused by poor hygiene. Sterilize the straw/substrate thoroughly before planting. Wash hands and tools with alcohol. Isolate and destroy any bag showing green spots immediately to save the rest of the room.

Tiny flies hover around the bags. Their maggots eat the mushroom spawn and tunnel into the stems. Treatment: Install "Light Traps" in the growing room to catch adults. Keep the room sealed with fine mesh nets. Ensure the growing medium is fully composted (no smell of ammonia) to avoid attracting flies.
Brown, slimy lesions on caps. Lower humidity. Water with chlorinated water.
Deformed, dry, leathery mushrooms. Control flies. Use clean casing.
Mushrooms rot into foul-smelling mass. Use clean tools. Remove infected clumps carefully.
Fluffy white mold covers the mushroom like a web. Treat with salt. Reduce humidity.
Mycelium disappears; mushrooms don't form. Pasteurize compost effectively.
Larvae tunnel into mushrooms. Use fly screens and traps.
Green fungal growth on compost/casing. Sterilize compost properly. Maintain hygiene.

The outer fleshy rind (used for pickles/vegetables) develops dark brown rotting patches and falls off before the nut matures. Treatment: Prune the tree to allow sunlight to reach the inner branches. Remove fallen, rotting fruits from the ground to stop spores from rising. Spray 1% Bordeaux mixture (copper + lime) before the monsoon starts.

White, thread-like fungal mycelium covers the underside of leaves and spreads to the fruit, causing rot. Prune infected branches and destroy them. Spray copper-based fungicides. Keep the tree canopy open.

The fruit splits open before maturity, exposing the mace and seed to rot. This is usually due to irregular watering or nutrient shock. Maintain consistent soil moisture. Apply Potash fertilizers. This is not a germ, so fungicides won't help.
Leaves develop holes, but the infection also causes necrotic spots on the fruit pericarp. Spray Mancozeb. Remove infected leaves.
Black coating on the fruit surface due to insect honeydew. Control scale insects with Neem oil. Wash the harvested pericarp with mild soapy water before processing.
Hard scales suck sap from the fruit skin, causing shriveling. Scrub off scales. Spray horticultural oil. Encourage natural predators.
The fruit turns black and mummifies on the tree. Remove and burn mummified fruits. Spray Copper Oxychloride. Avoid wounding the fruit during harvest.

Water-soaked lesions appear on the fruit skin, causing the pericarp to rot and split prematurely. Collect and burn fallen, infected fruits. Spray Bordeaux mixture (1%) before the monsoon starts. Prune the tree to reduce shade and humidity.

Black powdery streaks appear between the outer papery layers of the onion bulb, usually after harvest. Ensure the onions are "cured" (dried) properly. After harvest, leave them in a warm, dry, shaded area with good airflow for 2 weeks until the neck is tight and dry. Do not harvest wet onions. Handle bulbs gently to avoid bruising. Store in mesh bags.

The neck of the onion becomes soft and mushy, eventually rotting the bulb from the inside out. Stop watering the crop 10-14 days before harvest to let the tops dry out naturally. Ensure the neck is fully dry and tight before cutting the tops for storage. Cure onions in a dry, airy place for two weeks. Do not apply nitrogen fertilizer late in the season.

The leaves turn yellow and die back from the tip. The roots rot, and a white/pinkish mold grows at the base plate (bottom) of the bulb, making it soft. Treatment: This fungus lives in the soil for years. Practice a long crop rotation (4 years without onions/garlic). Solarize the soil in summer to kill the fungus. Buy treated seeds or sets. Ensure excellent drainage; raised beds are highly recommended. Remove infected plants immediately.

Small white maggots tunnel into the bulb, causing it to rot and wilt. Young seedlings may die completely. Treatment: This pest is attracted to the smell of rotting onions. Remove all "cull" (discarded) onions from the garden; never leave them in the soil. Rotate crops to a new location every year. Use floating row covers (mesh) immediately after planting to stop flies from laying eggs. Interplant with mint or marigolds to mask the onion scent.

While it starts on leaves as purple lesions, the infection travels down to the bulb, causing a semi-watery rot around the neck that turns yellow or red. Treatment: Improve air circulation by spacing plants properly. Avoid overhead watering. A spray of Mancozeb or a copper-based fungicide can protect the crop if the weather is warm and humid. Harvest only when the weather is dry.

#1 Pest. Leaves develop silvery-white streaks and curl. The bulbs remain small and twisted. Treatment: Thrips hide at the base of the leaf. Use Blue sticky traps (they are attracted to blue). Spray water forcefully into the leaf axils to wash them out. Mulch with straw to reduce their population.

Purplish, water-soaked spots on leaves and stalks cause the bulb to remain small and spongy. Spray Mancozeb mixed with a sticky agent (like soap). Ensure good drainage. Harvest only when tops are dry.
Small yellow/orange spots on leaves turn black, killing the foliage early and reducing bulb size. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid excessive nitrogen. Remove infected debris.
Maggots tunnel into the bulb, causing it to rot and wilt. Use floating row covers. Apply Neem cake to soil. Rotate crops (do not plant after onions/garlic).
The base of the bulb rots; roots turn pink/brown. Soil-borne fungus. Use resistant varieties. Solarize soil. Treat seeds with Trichoderma.
Grey mold rots the neck and bulb during storage. "Cure" onions thoroughly (dry the necks) before storage. Store in cool, ventilated area. Avoid late nitrogen fertilizer.
Black powdery mold under the outer scales of the bulb. Common in hot, humid storage. Keep storage dry (below 70% humidity). Handle bulbs gently to avoid bruising.
Tiny insects cause silvery streaks on leaves; bulbs don't grow well. Spray Imidacloprid or Neem oil. Use blue sticky traps.

A white, powdery coating develops on leaves, stems, and pods. Leaves turn yellow and dry up. Treatment: Plant early to avoid the warm weather that the fungus loves. Space plants widely. Spray sulphur powder or a baking soda mixture (1 tsp soda, 1 tsp oil, 4 liters water) at the first sign of white dust.
White powder on pods and leaves; pods become discolored and bitter. Spray wettable sulfur. Plant resistant varieties. Harvest early.
Larvae bore holes into pods and eat seeds. Handpick damaged pods. Spray Neem oil. Install bird perches.
Dark, sunken spots on pods and leaves. Seeds inside may have dark spots. Use disease-free seeds. Rotate crops. Spray Chlorothalonil if severe.
Brown pustules on leaves and pods. Dust sulfur. Remove crop residues. Avoid sprinkler irrigation.
Large green aphids suck sap, deforming pods and spreading viruses. Spray soapy water. Encourage ladybugs.
Yellow patches on leaves; grey fuzz on pods. Spray Metalaxyl. Avoid overcrowding.
Plants yellow and die; roots rot. Use wilt-resistant varieties. Rotate crops for 5 years.

Major Pest: The fly lays eggs inside the pod wall. The maggot eats the green seed from the inside. The pod looks normal outside but the seed is destroyed. Treatment: This is hard to see until harvest. Use "Sticky Traps" to catch flies. Spray a mixture of Neem oil and Soap water during the pod formation stage. Harvest the green pods slightly early before the maggots fully develop.

The plant looks bushy and pale green but produces no flowers or pods. It effectively becomes sterile. Treatment: This is spread by mites. There is no cure for the plant. Identify these "barren" plants early and pull them out immediately to stop the mites from spreading to healthy neighbors. Sulphur sprays can help control the mite population.
Maggots feed on developing seeds inside the pod without showing external holes (except exit hole). Spray Neem oil or systemic insecticide during early pod formation.
Leaves are pale and bushy; no flowers or pods form ("green plague"). Remove infected plants immediately. Control mites which spread it. Use resistant varieties.
Plants wilt and die; purple band on the stem. Use resistant varieties (e.g., Asha). Rotate with sorghum. Soil solarization helps.
Water-soaked lesions on stems and pods; plants rot. Ensure drainage (plant on ridges). Spray Metalaxyl.
Bugs suck sap from green pods; seeds shrivel. Spray Neem oil. Collect and destroy bugs.
Dry root rot; stems turn ash-grey and crack. Retain soil moisture during dry spells. Treat seeds with Trichoderma.
Caterpillars bore into pods and eat seeds. Shake plants to dislodge larvae. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Indoxacarb. Use pheromone traps.

The vine suddenly wilts, and the fruits turn soft, dark, and rotten (often with white mold). Treatment: This crop hates "wet feet." Do not let water stagnate. Stake the plants so vines don't touch the wet soil. Remove rotting fruits immediately. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-fungicide) during the monsoon.

Plants look stunted and yellow despite watering. Roots have knotty, wart-like swellings. Treatment: Apply Neem Cake (250g per pit) while planting. Plant marigolds around the field borders (their roots repel nematodes). Rotate crops; do not plant Parwal in the same spot for more than 2 years.
Maggots rot the fruit. Use pheromone traps. Collect fallen fruits.
Galls on roots; weak vines; small fruits. Apply Neem cake. Rotate crops.
Yellow spots on leaves; poor fruit set. Spray Metalaxyl. Prune dense vines.
Mottled, deformed fruits. Remove infected vines. Control aphids.
Beetles eat leaves; skeletonized vines yield poorly. Handpick beetles. Spray Neem oil.
Orange beetles eat flowers and young fruit skin. Dust ash. Handpick in morning.
Water-soaked spots on fruit covered with white mold. Avoid fruit contact with soil (trellising). Spray Mancozeb. Remove rotting fruits.

The potato skin turns green due to sun exposure, producing toxic solanine. "Hill up" soil around the base of the plant as it grows to ensure developing tubers remain buried in the dark. If a potato pokes out of the soil, cover it with soil or straw immediately. Discard the green parts before cooking, as they are unsafe to eat.

The potato looks normal outside but has a hollow cavity inside. This is caused by very rapid growth due to excessive watering or too much fertilizer. Plant potatoes closer together to increase competition and slow down individual tuber growth. Maintain steady, consistent moisture rather than flooding the plants after a dry spell. Avoid heavy nitrogen applications.

Larvae tunnel into the tuber, filling it with waste (frass) and causing rot. This can happen in the field or in storage. Treatment: "Hill up" the soil properly so moths cannot reach the tubers through cracks in the ground. Harvest immediately once the crop is ready; do not leave them in the ground. Cover harvested piles with a clean cloth to prevent moths from laying eggs before storage. Use pheromone traps.

The skin shows brownish-purple blotches, and the flesh underneath turns reddish-brown and granular. Treatment: This spreads from infected leaves. If you see blight on leaves (black spots), cut the stems (haulms) 2 weeks before harvest to stop spores from washing down to the tubers. Wait for the skin to harden before digging. Harvest on a dry day. Destroy all infected plant parts; do not compost them.

Specific to Nilgiris/Kodaikanal. Plants are stunted, yellow, and wilt during the day. Roots have tiny golden/brown cysts clinging to them. Treatment: This is a quarantined pest. Rotate crops with non-solanaceous plants (like carrots or beans) for 2-3 years. Use nematode-resistant potato varieties (like "Kufri Swarna"). Solarize the soil before planting.

The most devastating disease. Leaves turn black; tubers develop reddish-brown, dry, granular rot. Spray Mancozeb or Metalaxyl immediately. Destroy infected haulms (tops) before harvest. Use resistant varieties.
Concentric "target board" rings on leaves; tubers may have sunken lesions. Spray Chlorothalonil. Maintain plant vigor with fertilizer.
Rough, corky, scabby spots on the tuber skin. Avoid alkaline soil (don't lime potatoes). Keep soil moist during tuber formation. Use scab-free seed.
Larvae mine into leaves and tunnel deep into stored tubers. Keep tubers well-covered with soil in the field. Store in cool conditions with Lantana leaves (repellent). Use pheromone traps.
Plants wilt; cut tubers ooze milky bacterial slime. Use disease-free seed. Rotate with cereals. Do not cut seed potatoes (plant whole).
Black, dirt-like crusts (sclerotia) on tuber skin that won't wash off. Use clean seed. Treat seed with Boric acid or fungicides. Harvest as soon as vines die.

The fruit develops soft, water-soaked, dark spots where it touches the soil. White or black mold often grows on these spots, turning the pumpkin into mush. Treatment: Prevention is key. Never let the pumpkin sit on bare earth. Place a wooden board, flat stone, or a thick bed of dry straw under every developing fruit. Avoid watering in the evening so the soil surface isn't wet overnight. Harvest immediately if a small spot appears.

The fruit becomes bumpy ("warty"), mottled with yellow and green patches, and often deformed. The plant growth is stunted. Treatment: There is no cure for the virus. Remove and burn the infected plant immediately to save the rest of the garden. The virus is spread by aphids, so control them using yellow sticky traps or insecticidal soap sprays. Sterilize pruning shears with alcohol after touching an infected plant.

Bright orange/red beetles eat holes in the leaves of seedlings, sometimes killing them. Treatment: They are active in the morning. Handpick them. Dust the leaves with wood ash or a mix of ginger-chilli extract. The grubs live in the soil, so deep ploughing in summer helps.
Maggots rot the fruit. Bag fruits. Use traps. Destroy fallen fruit.
White powder on leaves; stems wither; fruits sunscald. Spray wettable sulfur. Plant resistant varieties.
Yellow spots on leaves; fruit quality drops. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid wet foliage.
Bumpy, mottled, deformed fruits ("warty"). Remove plants. Control aphids.
Soft rot starts where fruit touches soil. Place straw or a wooden board under the fruit. Avoid overwatering.
Beetles eat flowers/young fruit. Handpick. Dust ash.
Black rot on fruit; stems ooze gum. Rotate crops. Spray Chlorothalonil.

Dark, sunken spots or black streaks appear on the white root, eventually cracking it. This occurs in cool, wet soils. Rotate crops; do not plant radishes in the same spot where cabbage or mustard grew previously. Improve soil drainage in the bed. Harvest radishes as soon as they are ready; leaving them in the ground too long drastically increases disease risk.

Small white maggots tunnel through the root, leaving rusty-brown trails and causing rot. The plant may wilt even if watered. Treatment: Cover the seedbed with a "floating row cover" (fine mesh) immediately after planting to stop flies from laying eggs. Interplant with strong-smelling herbs like mint or marigolds to mask the radish scent. Sprinkle wood ash around the base of the plants. Harvest the entire crop before the soil gets too warm.

The root looks normal outside, but when cut, the inside is spongy, dry, and white (pithy) or has a hollow center. Treatment: This happens when radishes are left in the ground too long past maturity or face heat stress. Treatment: Harvest promptly as soon as the roots reach edible size (usually 25-30 days). Maintain consistent soil moisture. Mulch to keep the soil cool. Avoid planting in the peak heat of summer.

White, raised, blister-like pustules appear on the undersides of leaves. The leaves may deform or twist. Treatment: This is common in cool, damp weather (like Ooty/Bangalore winters). Rotate crops (don't plant radish/mustard in the same spot). Remove infected leaves. Avoid overhead watering.

The root splits into two or more "legs" or looks twisted. Treatment: This is caused by stones, hard soil clumps, or fresh manure touching the root tip. Sift the soil well to remove stones. Use only fully decomposed compost. Do not transplant radish; always sow seeds directly.

White, raised blisters (pustules) appear on the leaves and sometimes deform the root itself. This is common in cool, damp weather. Harvest early if spots appear. Rotate crops (do not plant radish after mustard or cabbage). Destroy infected leaves.
Small white maggots tunnel into the radish, leaving brown, rotting trails. The root becomes inedible. Use floating row covers to exclude flies. Apply Neem cake to the soil. Do not use fresh manure.
The root turns black, particularly at the bacterial entry points or lateral roots. The flesh remains firm but is discolored. Improve drainage; this is a wet soil disease. Rotate crops for 3-4 years.
Corky, rough, raised spots on the root skin. It doesn't affect taste but ruins the look. Keep soil moisture consistent (do not let it dry out completely). Avoid alkaline soil (don't over-lime).
The core of the radish turns into a creamy, foul-smelling mush. Avoid overwatering. Harvest carefully to prevent skin cuts. Store in a cool, dry place.
Yellow spots on leaves; the root may develop internal brown discoloration/netting. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid overhead irrigation.
Dark spots on the crown (top of the root) lead to rot. Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove infected foliage immediately.

Grubs bore tunnels into the underground corm. The plant looks weak and yellow. Treatment: Use clean planting material. Dip suckers in Neem solution before planting. Keep the base of the plant earthed up and clean.

Major Pest in Kerala/TN. Small holes appear on the stem with jelly-like gum oozing out. The plant weakens and snaps in the wind. Treatment: Remove dried leaves from the stem (de-trashing) to remove hiding spots. Inject the stem with a diluted Neem oil emulsion using a syringe near the bore holes. Use pheromone traps specifically for banana weevils.

The lower leaves turn bright yellow and hang down around the stem like a skirt. The plant eventually dies. Treatment: This fungus lives in the soil for years. There is no cure for the infected plant; dig it out and burn it. Do not replant banana in that spot. Use resistant varieties like "Poovan" or "Nendran" derived from tissue culture.
The tip of the raw fruit dries out and looks like grey ash (cigar tip). Remove the flower pistils from the fruit tip manually in the field. Bag the bunches.
The fruit flesh develops a firm, brown, dry rot inside, even though the skin looks okay. Sterilize machetes with bleach between plants. Remove and burn infected mats immediately.
Beetles feed on the young fruit skin, leaving rough, raised scars. Bag the bunch with plastic/cloth covers as soon as the hands open. Keep the area weed-free.
Black sunken spots on the green skin; fruit ripens prematurely or rots. Spray Copper fungicide. Handle bunches gently.
White cottony masses between the fingers of the bunch. Spray soap solution or Neem oil. Control ants that farm them.
Trees topple over (topple disease); bunches are small. Pare (trim) the corms before planting to remove dark lesions. Hot water treat corms (55°C for 20 mins).
Grubs bore into the corm and stem; fruit bunches are small and may fall prematurely. Use clean suckers for planting. Trap weevils with cut pseudostem pieces.

Small wedge-shaped insects suck sap from flowers and young fruits. They secrete sticky "honeydew" that turns black (sooty mold). Treatment: This causes the young "vegetable" mangoes to drop off. Spray a strong jet of water to wash off the sticky honeydew. Spray Neem Azadirachtin (10,000 ppm) during the flowering stage to repel hoppers.

White, flour-like dust covers the flowers and young fruits. The tiny fruits turn black and fall off. Treatment: Prune the tree to open the center to sunlight. Spray wettable Sulphur (2g/liter) just before the flowers open. If the tree is large, dusting with sulphur powder is effective.
Black, raised, cracking spots on the green fruit skin that ooze gum. Prune infected twigs. Spray Streptocycline + Copper fungicide.
Maggots tunnel in; green fruit softens and drops. Use Methyl Eugenol traps. Harvest while fruit is fully mature but still hard.
Black sticky coating on green skin. Wash with soapy water. Control hoppers/scales on the tree.
Rusty red spots on the fruit skin. Prune for airflow. Spray Copper Oxychloride. Ensure tree nutrition.
White powder on young fruits causes russeting (scabby skin) and dropping. Dust sulfur during flowering/fruit set.
Black spots on green fruit ("Tear staining"). Spray Copper fungicide. Prune dead wood.
The grub bores directly into the stone; the green flesh rots from the inside out. Collect and destroy all fallen fruits. Spray Deltamethrin on the trunk during off-season.

Thin, white, winding trails (squiggles) appear on the leaves. The larvae are inside the leaf layers. Treatment: Since they are inside, surface sprays don't work well. Pinch the trails to kill the larvae. Remove heavily mined leaves. Hang yellow sticky traps to catch the adult flies.
Yellow/green mottling on leaves. Twisted fruits. Treatment: Remove infected plants. Control aphids/beetles.
Large red/orange beetles eat holes in leaves and flowers. Treatment: Handpick them in the early morning when they are slow. Dust wood ash on the leaves.
Maggots rot the fruit. Bag fruits with newspaper. Use pheromone traps. Destroy fallen fruit.
Yellow angular leaf spots; fruits stunt and taste bad. Spray Mancozeb. Train vines on trellis.
Mottled, deformed, "warty" fruits. Remove infected vines. Control aphids.
White powder on vines; fruits dry up. Spray wettable sulfur.
Cottony leak/soft rot where fruit touches soil. Trellis the plant. Improve drainage.
Galls on roots; weak vines; small fruits. Apply Neem cake. Rotate crops.
Beetles eat leaves; skeletonized vines yield poorly. Handpick beetles. Spray Neem oil.

The stem turns black and soft near the soil line. The plant wilts and dies. Treatment: The red calyx (fruit covering) is the edible part, so avoid systemic chemicals. Ensure the soil drains well. Rotate the crop annually. Solarize the soil in summer to kill the fungus.
White masses on the calyx make it inedible. Spray strong water jet. Use soap solution.
Black spots on the red calyx. Spray Mancozeb. Harvest frequently.
Larvae bore into the seed capsule inside the calyx. Spray Neem oil.
White dust on the calyx and leaves. Spray wettable sulfur.
Black aphids cluster on the calyx. Wash with salt water. Spray soapy water.
The whole plant wilts; vascular system turns brown. Rotate crops. Solarize soil.
The fleshy red calyx (fruit) rots; the stem turns black at the soil line. Ensure excellent drainage. Drench soil with Copper fungicide.

Major Pest: Flies puncture the tender skin of the round fruit to lay eggs. Maggots eat the inside, causing rot. Treatment: Tinda skin is very soft. Use pheromone traps (Methyl Eugenol) to catch male flies. Cover the fruits with cloth bags if growing on a small scale. Collect and bury fallen fruits deep in the soil.

White, flour-like dust covers the leaves and stems. The plant looks like it was dusted with ash. Treatment: This reduces the yield drastically. Prune dense leaves to let sunlight in. Spray wettable sulphur (2g/liter) or a mixture of baking soda and water (1 tsp/liter) early in the morning.
White powder; fruits sunscald. Spray wettable sulfur.
Deformed fruits. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Soft rot in wet weather. Avoid soil contact. Spray Mancozeb.
Beetles damage young fruit skin. Dust ash. Handpick.
Yellow leaf spots; poor yield. Spray Metalaxyl.
Sucks sap; transmits virus. Spray Neem oil. Use yellow sticky traps.
Maggots rot the fruit. Use traps. Bag fruits.

The leaves twist, curl, and elongate abnormally (looking like a spiral). The bulbs rot in the soil. Treatment: This is a major disease in Karnataka. Use raised beds to prevent water stagnation. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-agent) or a mild copper fungicide. Store bulbs in well-ventilated racks, not in heaps.
Roots rot; base of bulb turns brown. Use resistant varieties. Treat seed bulbs with Trichoderma.
Maggots tunnel into the small bulbs. Apply Neem cake. Rotate crops.
Silvery streaks on leaves; stunted bulbs. Spray Imidacloprid/Neem oil. Blue sticky traps.
Violet fungal growth on leaves. Spray Metalaxyl. Avoid overcrowding.
Black dust on stored bulbs. Keep storage dry. Cure bulbs well.
White mold with black specks at the base. Destroy infected plants. Long rotation.
Purplish spots on leaves; bulbs remain small. Spray Mancozeb with sticky agent. Harvest when dry.

Vines look weak and yellow despite watering. Roots have large galls or knots. Treatment: Kovakkai is a perennial crop (stays for years), so soil health is vital. Apply Neem cake (1kg per plant) once every 6 months. Intercrop with Marigolds to repel nematodes. Flood the basin with water occasionally to reduce nematode population.

White powder covers the leaves and stems, reducing yield. Treatment: Prune the vines heavily to reduce density. Spray wettable sulphur (2g/liter). Since fruits are harvested daily/weekly, avoid harsh chemicals.
White powder on vines. Spray wettable sulfur. Prune dense growth.
Mottled, knobbly fruits. Remove infected vines. Control aphids.
Larvae eat fruit. Handpick. Spray Neem oil.
Sunken spots on fruit. Spray Mancozeb.
Sooty mold on fruit. Spray soap solution.
Yellow leaf spots. Spray Metalaxyl.
Maggots rot the fruit. Trap males (Cue-lure). Bag fruits.

The fruit turns soft, watery, and dark brown, often covered in white cottony mold. This happens mostly when the fruit touches damp soil. Treatment: Snake gourds must be grown on a high trellis (pandal) so fruits hang straight and away from the soil. If a fruit touches the ground, place a stone or wood block under it. Remove rotting fruits immediately. Ensure soil drainage is good.

Green semi-looper caterpillars feed on the leaves and scrape the skin of young fruits, causing scarring and deformation. Treatment: Handpick and destroy caterpillars (they are often found on the undersides of leaves). Encourage birds in the garden. Spray a neem oil solution or Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) to kill the larvae without harming beneficial insects.
Stunted growth, galls on roots. Treatment: Apply neem cake. Intercrop with marigolds.

Swellings or galls appear on the main stem near the ground. The vine wilts above the gall. Treatment: Earth up soil around the nodes to encourage new roots above the gall. Apply Neem cake to the soil. Remove the affected plant if it wilts completely.
Maggots cause the long gourd to twist, rot, and yellow. Bag fruits with newspaper tubes. Use pheromone traps.
Gum oozes from stem; black spots on fruit. Spray Chlorothalonil. Rotate crops.
Soft rot where fruit touches soil (or Pythium). Hang a small stone at the tip to keep it straight and off the ground. Spray Mancozeb.
White powder on leaves/fruit. Spray wettable sulfur.
Green caterpillars eat leaves and young fruit skin. Handpick. Spray Neem oil.
Mottled, deformed fruits. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Galls on roots; weak vines. Apply Neem cake.

Small, water-soaked spots appear on leaves, turning into reddish-brown pustules. Leaves yellow and drop rapidly, leaving empty pods. Treatment: This is a major issue in North Karnataka. Monitor the crop daily. If rust appears, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Remove infected lower leaves. Do not over-irrigate.

This is the most damaging disease. Reddish-brown pustules appear on the leaves and pods, leading to premature leaf drop and shriveled beans. Monitor the field closely during flowering. Spray rust-specific fungicides like Hexaconazole or Propiconazole immediately upon spotting symptoms. Ensure plants are well-spaced for airflow. Destroy volunteer soybean plants in the off-season to break the cycle.

Pods develop irregular brown blotches and may twist or drop off. Seeds inside become moldy or shriveled. Use certified disease-free seeds. Treat seeds with Thiram or Captan before sowing. Rotate crops with non-legumes like corn. Spray Mancozeb during the pod-formation stage if the weather is wet and humid.

The seeds inside the pod develop distinct purple blotches, reducing market value. It is caused by the Cercospora fungus on the pod. Spray Benomyl or Carbendazim during the pod-filling stage. Harvest immediately when the crop is mature to reduce exposure. Use resistant varieties if available in your area.

Larvae bore holes into the green pods and eat the developing seeds. You will see frass (droppings) outside the holes. Install pheromone traps to catch adult moths. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Indoxacarb as a safe control measure. Encouraging birds by placing T-shaped perches in the field helps naturally reduce the larval population.

Leaves show bright yellow mosaic patches; pods are deformed, few, and contain small seeds. There is no cure for the plant. Remove and burn infected plants immediately. Control the whiteflies that spread the virus using yellow sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Keep the field free of weeds that host the virus.

This soil fungus blocks water flow, causing the plant to wilt and die. If you split the stem or root, it looks grey/black like charcoal dust. It thrives in hot, dry stress. Mulch the soil to retain moisture. Irrigate lightly and frequently. There is no chemical cure; crop rotation is the only prevention.

Raised, light-colored pustules appear on the leaves and pods, which can crack and merge. It thrives in warm, wet weather. Avoid cultivating the field when foliage is wet. Use resistant varieties. Clean up crop debris after harvest. Copper sprays can help protect healthy pods but cannot cure infected ones.

This vegetable is highly susceptible. Maggots bore into the spiny fruit, causing it to turn yellow prematurely and rot. Treatment: Since this is a monsoon crop, chemical sprays wash off. Use "Methyl Eugenol" pheromone traps to capture male flies. Harvest fruits while they are still small and tender to escape infestation. Destroy any fallen fruit instantly.

Small, dark, sunken spots appear on the leaves and fruits. The vine may yellow and weaken. Treatment: Use disease-free tubers/roots for planting. Provide a strong trellis support to keep vines off the wet ground. Remove infected leaves. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-agent) every 10 days.

Sunken, dark spots appear on the green fruit skin, making it rot or shrivel. Spray Mancozeb or Copper Oxychloride during fruit set. Prune the vines to allow sunlight to reach the inner fruits. Harvest regularly to prevent over-mature fruits from becoming infection hubs.

Yellow angular spots on leaves lead to weak vines and small, sun-scalded fruits. Spray Metalaxyl or Mancozeb. Avoid overhead irrigation that keeps leaves wet. Train the vines on a trellis to keep them off the damp soil.

Fruits become bumpy, mottled, and misshapen. Remove and destroy infected vines immediately. Control aphids with sticky traps or Neem oil. Sterilize your pruning shears with bleach between cuts to prevent spreading the virus manually.

Soft, watery rot starts at the blossom end or where the fruit touches the soil. Use trellises to keep fruit off the ground. Improve soil drainage. Remove rotting fruits immediately. Spray copper fungicide if rains are heavy.
White powder on leaves and stems reduces plant energy, causing fruits to drop or remain tiny. Spray wettable sulfur. Ensure good air circulation by thinning dense vines.
Roots develop galls; vines stunt and yield poorly. Apply Neem cake to the soil before planting. Rotate crops with marigolds. Solarize the soil during summer to kill nematodes.

Maggots bore into the fruit, causing soft rot and yellowing. This is the biggest yield killer. Bag the fruits with paper or cloth covers when they are small. Use pheromone traps (Cue-lure) to attract and kill male flies. Collect and bury all fallen, infested fruits deep in the soil to stop the next generation.

Leaves show yellow and green mottling, and fruits become small, twisted, and pale. Treatment: Remove and destroy the infected plant immediately to prevent spread. This virus is transmitted by aphids; control them using yellow sticky traps. Keep the garden weed-free, as weeds often host the virus.

The tip or bottom of the fruit turns soft and brown, often with white mold. This happens when fruits hang too close to damp soil or during heavy rains. Treatment: Ensure vines are trellised high. Remove rotting fruits immediately. Improve drainage around the plant roots. A preventative spray of neem oil can help during the rainy season.
Maggots tunnel into the young gourd, causing it to bend, yellow, and rot. Bag fruits early. Use pheromone traps. Collect and destroy fallen fruit to break the lifecycle.
Yellow spots on leaves cause defoliation; fruits remain small and may sunscald. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid overhead watering. Prune lower leaves to increase airflow.
Stems ooze a reddish gum; black rotting spots appear on the fruit. Rotate crops (don't plant gourds for 2 years). Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove plant debris after harvest.
White powder on leaves reduces yield. Spray wettable sulfur. Keep vines thinned out to reduce humidity.
Mottled, deformed, "warty" gourds. Remove infected vines. Control aphids. Keep the garden weed-free.
Cottony white mold develops on fruit in wet conditions ("Cottony Leak"). Improve drainage. Trellis the vines. Avoid fruit contact with soil.
The tip of the gourd turns black and rots. Ensure consistent watering. Add lime or calcium to the soil. Mulch to retain moisture.

Maggots bore into the ridges of the star fruit, causing it to rot and drop. Treatment: Harvest fruits as soon as the colour changes from green to light yellow; do not wait for them to turn fully orange on the tree. Use pheromone traps. Bag the best bunches with newspaper.
Small, dark spots on the fruit skin that merge and cause rotting. Spray copper fungicide. Prune the tree to open the canopy. Remove fallen fruits.
Black, sticky coating on the fruit surface. Control scale insects and mealybugs with Neem oil. Wash the fruit with soapy water before eating.
Small, water-soaked spots on the fruit that turn brown and corky. Avoid overhead irrigation. Spray copper fungicide. Prune infected twigs.
Waxy bumps on the fruit skin suck sap. Scrub off with a brush. Spray horticultural oil. Prune heavily infested branches.
