White cottony masses in the fruit ribs. Wash off with water spray. Use soap solution. Control ants.
Tree wilts; fruit drops. Caused by wet soil. Improve drainage. Drench soil with copper fungicide.
Larvae bore into the ripening fruit, causing rot. Wrap fruits in paper bags or mesh on the tree. Use pheromone traps. Harvest fruits just before they turn fully yellow to avoid infestation.

Rusty orange spots appear on the undersides of leaves. The tree may shed leaves early. Treatment: Collect and burn fallen leaves. Prune the tree to open up the canopy for sunlight. In severe cases, a sulphur spray helps, but usually, the tree recovers on its own.
Soft, brown rot on the berries, especially after rain. Harvest frequently. Remove rotting berries from the tree and ground. Spray copper fungicide.
Rusty pustules on leaves; berries may drop. Dust sulfur. Remove fallen leaves.
Black mold on berries due to aphid honeydew. Wash berries. Control aphids with Neem oil.
Scales on stems and fruit stems. Prune infested parts. Spray oil.
White wax on berries. Spray soap solution.
Brown spots cause leaf drop and poor fruiting. Spray Carbendazim.
Dark spots on fruit. Spray Mancozeb.

The leaves become small, curled, and bunched together. The plant stops flowering. Treatment: This wild relative of the brinjal is usually very hardy, but whiteflies can spread this virus. Remove the infected branch or plant immediately. Spray neem oil to keep whiteflies away. Keep the area around the bush weed-free.

Rare, but sometimes caterpillars bore into the green berries, causing them to hollow out and drop. Treatment: Since berries grow in clusters, check for webbing or holes. Handpick the damaged clusters. A simple spray of garlic-chilli extract is usually enough to repel pests from this hardy plant.
Plant wilts; vascular system browns. Rotate crops. Solarize soil.
Curled leaves; few berries. Control whiteflies. Remove infected plants.
Tiny leaves; bushy plant; no fruit. Remove plant. Control leafhoppers.
Galls on roots; weak plant. Apply Neem cake.
White powder on leaves/berries. Spray wettable sulfur.
Sucking insects on tips. Spray soap solution.
Larvae bore into the berries. Handpick damaged berries. Spray Neem oil.

Long, boat-shaped, greyish-green lesions appear on the lower leaves and spread upward. Leaves look "burnt." Treatment: Plant resistant hybrids. Rotate crops with non-grass plants (like beans). Remove lower infected leaves. Spray Mancozeb or neem oil if the infection appears early in the season.

You will see "pinholes" in the leaves in a straight line as they unfurl. The central shoot may dry up ("dead heart"). Treatment: Drop a pinch of granules or a mix of sand and neem powder into the central whorl (funnel) of the plant. This kills the larvae trying to enter the stem. Remove plants showing "dead hearts."

A devastating pest. Larvae hide deep in the central whorl (funnel) of the plant and eat the growing tip, leaving ragged holes and large amounts of sawdust-like waste. Treatment: Inspect the whorl of every plant. If you see waste, apply a pinch of sand mixed with lime or ash into the funnel (this irritates the larvae). Spray Metarhizium (bio-fungicide) or Neem formulation (10,000 ppm) directly into the whorl.
Larvae feed on the silk and the tip of the cob. Apply Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Spinosad to the silks. Mineral oil applied to the silk channel can suffocate larvae.
Large, grey, puffball-like galls form on the kernels. Remove galls immediately before they burst and release spores. Avoid mechanical injury to plants.
Brown pustules on husks and leaves. Plant resistant varieties. Spray wettable sulfur if infection is early. Destroy crop debris.
Grey, cigar-shaped lesions on leaves reduce yield. Spray Mancozeb. Rotate crops.
Stalks rot; ears drop or are small. Balance nitrogen. Avoid high plant density.
Yellow streaks on leaves; stunted cobs. Control aphids/leafhoppers. Remove infected plants.
Larvae cut seedlings; poor stand establishment. Collar seedlings. Handpick larvae.

Larvae tunnel through the tuber, leaving it honeycombed with holes and bitter-tasting. This is the worst pest for sweet potato. "Hill up" soil around the base to close cracks so weevils cannot reach the tubers. Rotate crops annually. Use pheromone traps to monitor. Harvest promptly once mature; do not leave tubers in the ground for "storage."

This is the #1 enemy. Larvae tunnel through the tuber, leaving it honeycombed with holes and waste. The tuber becomes bitter and inedible. Treatment: "Hill up" (pile) soil around the base of the plant to fill cracks; weevils can't dig, they only enter through open cracks. Use pheromone traps to catch males. Harvest promptly once mature. Rotate crops; do not plant sweet potatoes in the same spot for 3 years.

Also known as "Bread Mold," this turns the tuber soft, watery, and stringy. It often smells like alcohol/fermentation and develops black "whiskers." Treatment: This usually enters through cuts during harvest. Handle tubers gently like eggs. "Cure" them immediately after harvest (keep in a warm, humid room for 5-7 days) to heal skin wounds before storage. Do not store in cold refrigerators; they need cool, dry air (13-15°C).

Large, sunken, circular black spots appear on the tuber. If you cut into the spot, the rot is shallow but the taste is bitter. Treatment: This spreads from infected "slips" (planting vines). Use only certified disease-free slips. Do not wash tubers before curing/storage, as water spreads spores. Practice crop rotation (3-4 years). If you see black lesions on the stems near the soil line, remove the plant immediately.

Dark brown or black stains appear on the skin, looking like coffee stains. It is only skin-deep and doesn't affect the flesh, but it looks bad and causes moisture loss (shriveling) in storage. Treatment: Use vine cuttings (slips) cut at least 2cm above the soil line to ensure they are clean. Do not plant in wet, heavy soil or areas where manure was recently applied. Scurf loves moisture, so ensure good drainage.

Large, C-shaped white grubs eat large gouges or shallow holes out of the tuber skin and flesh. Treatment: These grubs live in the soil (often from beetles). Deep plow or dig over the soil in summer to expose grubs to birds and sun. Avoid planting immediately after clearing a grassy area (grubs love grass roots). Applying neem cake to the soil during planting reduces the population.

Caterpillars fold the leaf over themselves using silk webbing and eat from the inside. Treatment: You will see folded leaves. Squeeze the folded leaf to kill the larva inside or pick it off. Since Sweet Potato has lush foliage, minor damage is fine, but severe infestation needs a Neem spray.

Large gnaw marks on the tubers; tubers are hollowed out. Treatment: Keep the field clean of tall grass where rats hide. Set up bamboo traps. Use "live traps." Placing owl perches (T-shaped poles) in the field encourages owls to hunt the rats at night.
The worst pest. Grubs tunnel through the tuber, causing honeycomb damage and bitterness. Earth up soil to cover tubers. Use pheromone traps. Rotate crops.
Circular, metallic black spots on the tuber; bitter taste. Use disease-free vine cuttings. Rotate crops for 3 years.
Brown/black staining on the skin (cosmetic). Use certified seed roots. Dip cuttings in fungicide.
Tubers turn soft and sweet-smelling (fermented) in storage or wet soil. Cure tubers before storage. Avoid bruising.
Vines yellow and die; tubers rot at the stem end. Plant resistant varieties. Avoid water stress.
Tubers crack and deform. Solarize soil. Rotate with grains.
Yellow spots on leaves; cracked tubers. Use virus-free vines. Control aphids.

The plant suddenly wilts. The roots turn black and decay. Treatment: Sword bean is hardy but hates waterlogging. Ensure the planting pit has excellent drainage. Do not overwater. Mix Trichoderma (bio-fungicide) with compost and apply it to the base of the plant.
Wilting, black roots. Treatment: Ensure good drainage. Apply Trichoderma.
Larvae bore into the large pods. Handpick. Spray Neem oil.
Sunken spots on pods. Spray Mancozeb.
Pustules on leaves. Dust sulfur.
Wilt; black roots. Improve drainage. Treat seeds.
White dust on pods. Spray wettable sulfur.
Deformed pods. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Sucking sap causes sooty mold. Spray soap solution.

Small holes appear on the fruit pods. Inside, a caterpillar eats the pulp and seeds, filling the pod with black waste. Treatment: Shake the tree branches to dislodge larvae. Collect and burn all fallen pods. If the tree is small enough, spray a garlic-chilli extract. Encourage weaver ants (red ants) in the tree, as they are natural predators of these borers.

White dusty powder covers the new tender leaves and young flowers, causing them to drop off before setting fruit. Treatment: This happens during cool, foggy mornings. Prune crowded branches to let sunlight in. Spraying a dilute sulphur solution (wettable sulphur) during the flowering stage helps save the crop.
Larvae bore into the pods and eat the pulp/seeds. Spray Neem oil. Harvest timely.
White powder on leaves and young pods. Spray wettable sulfur.
Black mold on pods due to insect honeydew. Wash pods. Control scale/mealybugs.
Scales on pods suck sap. Spray horticultural oil.
White wax on pods. Spray soap solution.
Pods rot in wet weather. Prune tree. Remove bad pods.
Dark spots on leaves/pods. Spray copper fungicide.

White, hard, waxy scales cover the stems, looking like white fungus. They suck sap, drying out the stem. Treatment: Select only clean, healthy stems for planting. If scales are seen on young plants, scrub them off with a toothbrush dipped in soapy water. Discard heavily infested stems; do not compost them.

Brown spots with dark borders appear on older leaves, causing them to yellow and fall off prematurely. Treatment: This is very common but usually doesn't kill the plant. Ensure wide spacing between plants for airflow. Remove fallen leaves from the ground. Maintain good soil nutrition (potash) to help the plant resist the fungus.

The tuber rots in the ground, becoming soft and smelly. The leaves may turn yellow and wilt. Treatment: This happens in waterlogged soil. Ensure good drainage; plant on mounds or ridges. Do not harvest during heavy rains. If rot is seen, harvest early to save the rest.

Common in TN/Kerala. Tiny red mites infest the underside of leaves. Leaves turn yellowish-brown, dusty, and dry up. Webs may be visible. Treatment: Spray the undersides of leaves with a strong jet of water to wash them off. Spray wettable sulphur or Neem oil. Mites love dust, so keep the field edges clean and dust-free.

Major Disease. Angular, water-soaked spots on leaves. Leaves dry up and fall ("candle" appearance of the stem). Gum oozes from stems. Treatment: Use disease-free stem cuttings. Rotate crops. Remove and burn infected plants. Dip cuttings in hot water (60°C for 20 mins) before planting.

White, cottony masses on stems and leaves. Treatment: Release parasitic wasps (Anagyrus lopezi) if available. Spray neem oil or soap solution. Avoid using broad-spectrum pesticides that kill beneficial insects.
Dark brown dry rot inside the tuber; stems show brown streaks. Use clean planting material. Harvest early.
Soft, foul-smelling rot in waterlogged soil. Improve drainage. Harvest in dry weather.
Water-soaked spots on leaves; gum on stems. Use resistant varieties. Clean tools.
White masses on shoot tips; stunts growth. Spray soap solution or Neem oil. Release parasitic wasps.
Scales on stems reduce vigor. Dip cuttings in soap solution before planting.
Galls on feeder roots; tubers small. Rotate crops. Apply Neem cake.
Leaves show yellow/green mosaic and curl; tubers fail to bulk. Use virus-free stems. Remove infected plants. Control whiteflies.

The plant growth stunts. When harvested, the underground corm (tuber) is soft, mushy, and smells bad. Treatment: Ensure water does not stagnate in the field. Treat seed corms with Trichoderma (bio-agent) or dip in hot water (50°C) before planting. Apply plenty of Neem cake to the soil to suppress soil fungi.
Soft, mushy rot of the corm. Ensure drainage. Use clean seed corms.
Dry, powdery rot in storage. Cure corms. Store in dry place.
Feather-like patterns on leaves; deformed corms. Use virus-free suckers. Control aphids.
Swellings on corm. Solarize soil. Hot water treat seed.
Sucking sap; transmitting virus. Spray soap solution.
White mold at base; corm rots. Deep ploughing. Apply Neem cake.
Dark, circular lesions on leaves; severe infection rots the corm. Spray Mancozeb. Remove infected leaves.

Small, dark, sunken spots appear on the leaves and fruits. The vine may yellow and weaken. Treatment: Use disease-free tubers for planting. Provide a strong trellis support to keep vines off the wet ground. Remove infected leaves. Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens (bio-agent) every 10 days.
Sunken spots on fruit. Spray Mancozeb.
Plant dies; roots rot. Rotate crops.
White powder on vines. Spray wettable sulfur.
Deformed fruits. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Larvae eat fruit. Spray Neem oil.
Galls on roots. Apply Neem cake.
Maggots rot the fruit. Bag fruits. Use traps.

A large black beetle bores into the crown (top) of the tree, chewing through the unopened fronds. When the leaf opens, it has V-shaped cuts. Treatment: Prevention is key. Hook out the beetle from the hole using a metal hook. Fill the hole with a mixture of sand and Neem cake (or salt) to stop re-entry. Hang pheromone traps ("Rhino Lure") in the garden.
Beetle bores into the crown; leaves show V-cuts; yield drops. Use pheromone traps. Hook out beetles with a metal rod. Treat crown with Neem oil/sand mix.
Larvae bore into the trunk; tree dies. Inject Carbaryl or Neem oil into the trunk. Use pheromone traps.
The central heart leaf rots and smells foul; nuts drop. Clean the crown. Apply Bordeaux paste. Protect from heavy rain.
Reddish-brown liquid oozes from trunk cracks; nuts shrivel. Chisel out infected bark and apply tar. Apply Neem cake to roots.
Triangular patches on the nut skin; nuts are small and scarred. Apply Neem oil-garlic soap mixture to the bunches. Apply micronutrients to the root.

Disease Name (Type): Ganoderma Wilt / Basal Stem Rot (Fungal Infection)
Treatment Methods: Bracket fungi at the base; tree wilts; nuts drop. Dig trench around tree to isolate. Apply Trichoderma and Neem cake.
Rats eat into the tender nuts. Place bromadiolone cakes in the crown. Use metal bands on the trunk to stop climbing.

Hill Station Crop (Ooty/Kodaikanal). White powdery growth covers the leaves. Leaves turn yellow and drop, exposing fruits to sunscald. Treatment: Prune the tree to open the canopy for airflow. Spray a mixture of baking soda and water (1 tsp per liter) or wettable sulphur.
Green insects cluster on the undersides of leaves, causing yellowing and distortion. Treatment: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap. Keep the area weed-free.
White powdery growth on leaves and fruit stalks; fruits may drop early or develop rough skin. Spray wettable sulfur. Ensure the tree is not too shaded by other canopy trees.
Green or black insects cluster on fruit stems, sucking sap and leaving sticky honeydew that turns into black sooty mold on the fruit. Spray Neem oil or soapy water.
Maggots tunnel into the ripening fruit, causing soft rot. Use pheromone traps. Collect and bury fallen fruits. Harvest slightly early if the infestation is severe.
Small white flies underneath leaves cause sooty mold on fruits and transmit viruses. Spray Neem oil or use yellow sticky traps.
Dark brown or black lesions on the fruit, often starting at the stem end. Avoid bruising the fruit. Store in a cool, dry place. Spray Mancozeb.
Leaves are mottled; fruits are small, hard, and unevenly ripened. Remove infected trees. Control aphids and whiteflies.

Dark, sunken, concentric rings appear on the ripe fruit, causing rot. Prune the tree to improve airflow. Spray Copper Oxychloride during fruit set. Harvest fruits immediately when ripe; do not leave them on the tree.

Caterpillars roll the leaves into a tube and live inside, eating the green tissue. Treatment: You will see rolled leaves clearly. Squeeze the roll by hand to crush the larva inside. If infestation is high, spray a contact bio-pesticide like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

The most destructive disease. Rhizomes turn soft, mushy, and water-soaked. Leaves yellow and dry up. Ensure good drainage (raised beds). Drench soil with Copper Oxychloride or Ridomil. Treat seed rhizomes with Trichoderma.
Tiny, hard scales infest rhizomes in the field and storage, sucking sap and causing shriveling. Discard infested seed rhizomes. Dip seeds in Quinalphos or soap solution before storage/planting.
Brown spots on leaves reduce photosynthesis, leading to very small, poor-quality rhizomes. Spray Mancozeb or Carbendazim. Mulch with green leaves to prevent soil splash.
Rhizomes appear dry and powdery inside; growth is stunted. Treat seed material with Carbendazim. Solarize the soil before planting. Avoid water stress.
Larvae bore into the central shoot, causing "dead heart." The rhizome stops growing. Spray Neem oil or Dimethoate. Cut and burn dead shoots.
Rhizomes develop lesions and galls; plants look stunted. Apply Neem cake (2 tons/ha) to the soil. Rotate crops with marigolds.
Rhizomes rot in the pit due to moisture/heat. Cure rhizomes properly after harvest. Store in dry sand or sawdust in a ventilated area.

Small yellow spots appear on leaves, which turn brown with concentric rings (target-board shape). Treatment: This happens in cool, wet weather (common in Karnataka hill stations). Remove lower infected leaves. Avoid overhead watering. Rotate crops with non-crucifers (avoid planting after cabbage/cauliflower).
Dark spots on leaves; infection can travel to the root crown, causing black rot. Spray Chlorothalonil. Remove infected leaves.
Veins blacken; the internal root flesh turns grey/black. Use hot-water treated seeds. Rotate crops. Remove infected plants.
The root turns into a creamy, foul-smelling mush. Avoid overwatering. Harvest carefully to prevent cuts. Store cool and dry.
Roots become swollen, misshapen clubs. Apply lime to raise soil pH. Do not plant turnips in infected soil for 5+ years.
Maggots tunnel into the root, leaving brown trails. Use row covers. Apply Neem cake. Rotate crops.
Rough, corky spots on the root skin. Keep soil moist (don't let it dry out). Avoid alkaline soil.
Internal root discoloration; yellow leaf spots. Spray Mancozeb. Avoid wet foliage.

Bright yellow patches appear on the leaves against the green background. Pods may be deformed. Treatment: Remove the infected plant to stop the spread. This is spread by aphids. Control aphids using yellow sticky traps and neem oil. Keep the area around the trellis weed-free.
Brown spots on leaves. Treatment: Remove infected leaves. Improve airflow. Spray mild fungicide if severe.
Larvae bore holes into the 4-angled pods. Handpick damaged pods. Spray Neem oil.
Orange galls/warts appear on the leaves and pods, deforming them. Remove infected parts immediately. Spray Mancozeb.
Black sunken spots on the pods. Spray Copper fungicide. Use clean seeds.
White powder on pods and leaves. Spray wettable sulfur.
Bright yellow patches; deformed pods. Control whiteflies. Remove infected plants.
Black aphids on pods causing sooty mold. Spray soapy water.
Brown spots; premature leaf fall reduces pod yield. Spray Carbendazim.

Young fruits drop off the tree in large numbers before maturing. Treatment: This is often due to moisture stress or Boron deficiency. Water the tree regularly during fruit set; do not let the soil crack. A soil application of Borax (50g per tree) can help retain the fruit.
Molds enter through cracks in the hard shell, rotting the pulp. Harvest intact fruits. Store in a dry place.
Larvae bore into the fruit while the shell is soft. Spray Neem oil during fruit setting. Bag the fruits.
Rough, scabby lesions on the fruit shell. Prune infected branches. Spray Copper Oxychloride.
Dark spots on the shell; premature fruit drop. Spray Mancozeb.
Black coating on the shell due to insect honeydew. Wash fruit. Control scale insects.
Scales on the hard shell suck sap. Scrub off. Spray horticultural oil.
Leaves show yellow/green mottling and distortion. Tubers remain small. Treatment: Remove infected plants immediately. Control whiteflies using sticky traps. Use clean tubers for planting next season.
Stunted plants; small, deformed tubers. Remove infected plants. Control aphids.
Plants wilt; tubers rot in soil. Improve drainage. Treat seeds with Trichoderma.
Galls on tubers. Solarize soil. Apply Neem cake.
Larvae bore into tubers in the field or storage. Earth up soil. Store in sand.
White masses on tubers and stems. Spray soap solution.
White mold at the stem base; tuber rots. Deep ploughing. Remove infected soil.
Water-soaked spots on leaves; tubers may rot. Use clean seed. Avoid overhead watering.

The stem swells and splits near the ground level. Leaves turn yellow, and the plant dies. Maggots tunnel inside the stem. Treatment: This attacks young seedlings. Earth up (mound soil) around the base of the plant to cover the damage and encourage new roots. Remove and destroy infected plants. Drench the soil with neem solution.

Water-soaked spots appear on leaves and pods. The spots turn brown and papery with a yellow halo. Treatment: Use disease-free seeds. Avoid working in the garden when plants are wet. Remove infected leaves. Spray a copper-based fungicide to protect healthy parts. Rotate crops annually.
Brownish-green bugs suck sap from the pods, causing them to shrivel and twist. Treatment: Shake the vines to drop the bugs into a bucket of water. Spray Neem oil. Remove weeds that host the bugs.
Larvae bore into the long pods. Handpick. Spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) or Neem oil.
Black aphids cover the pod tips ("Cowpea aphid"). Spray strong water jet or soap solution.
Sunken reddish-brown spots on pods. Spray Mancozeb. Use clean seed.
Pustules on leaves/pods. Dust sulfur. Remove crop residues.
White dust on pods. Spray wettable sulfur.
Mottled, stringy, deformed pods. Remove plants. Control aphids.
Plant yellows and dies; pods shrivel. Rotate crops. Use wilt-resistant varieties.
